template.name: AWS_Cloud Migration Factory
template.desc: With Cloud Migration Factory on AWS, you can automate manual processes and efficiently integrate multiple migration tools. This automated AWS Solution offers an orchestration platform, and predefined pipeline templates to improve performance and prevent long cutover windows throughout the migration process. The solution accelerates migration and uses AWS Application Migration Service (AWS MGN) to migrate your workloads to AWS at scale. AWS Professional Services, AWS Partners, and other enterprises currently use this solution to automate large-scale migrations.

dataflow.name: Migration automation server -> AWS API Gateway
AWS Systems Manager -> Migration automation server
Tools Functions -> AWS Application Migration Service
Migration automation server -> AWS Secrets Manager

weakness.name: CWE-1047
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1047: Modules with Circular Dependencies The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

weakness.name: CWE-1193
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1193: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-312
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-416
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-416: Use After Free Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-672
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-672: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply permission boundaries to cap Lambda role and user privileges
countermeasure.desc:
Define a single IAM permission-boundary policy that represents the maximum set of actions a Lambda workload should ever performtypically the core lambda:*, CloudWatch Logs calls, and tightly scoped access to specific AWS resources. Attach that boundary to:

  • Every Lambda execution role (via the PermissionBoundary property in CloudFormation/Terraform).
  • All human or CI/CD principals that can create or update functions.

Because AWS evaluates the boundary before attached or inline policies, anything not explicitly allowed by the boundary is automatically deniedeven if someone tries to grant broader rights later.

quick implementation

  1. Author and publish the boundary
    1. {
       "Version":"2012-10-17",
       "Statement":[
         { "Effect":"Allow", "Action":[
             "lambda:*",
             "logs:CreateLogGroup", "logs:CreateLogStream", "logs:PutLogEvents"
           ], "Resource":"*" },
         { "Effect":"Deny", "Action":[ "iam:*", "organizations:*", "lambda:DeleteFunction" ], "Resource":"*" }
       ]
      }
       
    2. aws iam create-policy --policy-name lambda-boundary --policy-document file://boundary.json
  2. Attach the boundary
    1. aws iam put-role-permissions-boundary \
          --role-name OrderProcessorRole \
          --permissions-boundary arn:aws:iam::<acct>:policy/lambda-boundary
  3. Enforce automatically
    • Add a pipeline check (e.g., cfn-lint, Checkov) that fails if a new role lacks PermissionBoundary.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-permissions-boundary-check and create a similar custom rule for roles to detect drift.
  4. Maintain
    Review the boundary every quarter: remove unused Allow actions, add new ones only after peer approval, and keep the policy version history in source control.

References

  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities
  • Lambda security best practices IAM boundaries

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)

PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Deploy VPC Lambda functions across multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
For every Lambda function that runs inside a VPC, attach at least two private subnets that reside in different Availability Zones (AZs). Lambda automatically spreads function instances across all subnets you specify, so providing subnets in multiple AZs gives the function resiliency against an AZ-level failure.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet planning In the target VPC, create two or more /24 (or smaller) private subnets, each located in a distinct AZ (for example, subnet-az1a-private, subnet-az1b-private). If the function needs outbound internet access, give every AZ its own NAT gateway or egress path.
  2. Configure the function
    • Console: Configuration VPC Edit select the VPC and tick both (or all) private subnets.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
      • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
         --function-name order-processor \
         --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0a12,subnet-0b34,SecurityGroupIds=sg-0abc
  3. Security groups Attach a least-privilege security group that allows only the ports and CIDRs the function truly needs (for example, TCP 5432 to an RDS cluster SG).
  4. Guardrails Implement an AWS Config custom rule or cfn-nag check that fails a deployment when a VPC-connected Lambda lists fewer than two subnets.
  5. Validation & monitoring Use the Lambda consoles Monitoring Subnet metrics or CloudWatchs Duration metrics to confirm invocations appear from each AZ. Include a canary test that fires if an AZs invocations drop to zero.

Spreading subnets across Availability Zones ensures the function continues to invoke even if one AZor its networking componentsbecomes unavailable.

References

  • AWS Lambda resilience guidance
  • Create more than one subnet across different AZ

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Lambda env vars and code artifacts with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Safeguard every sensitive value that AWS Lambda storesenvironment variables, .zip deployment packages, container images, and event-filter criteriaby encrypting them with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of the default AWS-managed key. Using your own CMK lets you control key rotation, scope decrypt permissions tightly, and audit every use.

1 . Create or choose a CMK

aws kms create-key --description "Lambda data-at-rest CMK"
aws kms enable-key-rotation --key-id <key-id>

Limit the key policy to the Lambda service principal and the minimal set of roles that need kms:Decrypt / kms:GenerateDataKey.

2 . Encrypt environment variables

  • Console / IaC: set the KMS key ARN field (CloudFormation KmsKeyArn, Terraform kms_key_arn).
  • CLI:
    • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
          --function-name order-processor \
          --kms-key-arn arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd

Lambda now uses your CMK to encrypt Env Vars and event-filter JSON.

3 . Protect deployment artifacts

  • .zip packages in S3 store them in a bucket with SSE-KMS and the same CMK:
    • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
          --bucket lambda-artifacts-prod \
          --server-side-encryption-configuration \
          '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":
             {"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/lambda-data"}}]}'
  • Container images in ECR ensure the ECR repository uses KMS encryption with your CMK.

4 . Grant least-privilege KMS access

Add this statement (scoped to the CMK ARN) to the functions execution role:

{
 "Effect": "Allow",
 "Action": [
   "kms:Decrypt",
   "kms:GenerateDataKey*"
 ],
 "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd"
}

5 . Continuous assurance

  • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-env-vars-encrypted (or a custom rule) to flag functions without a CMK.
  • Create CloudWatch alarms on KMS metric NumberOfFailedDecryptRequests.
  • Rotate the CMK annually; update KmsKeyArn in templates, then disable the old key after confirming no decrypt errors.

Encrypting Lambda data with your own KMS keys gives you full custody of cryptographic material, meets stringent compliance mandates, and lets you trace every decrypt back to an invoking principal.

References

  • Encrypting environment variables and artifacts with a customer-managed KMS key
  • Using AWS KMS keys with AWS Lambda

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enforce bootstrap-aware CI/CD reviews and linting
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the security countermeasure that safeguards AWS Lambda custom runtimes by treating 'bootstrap' and Lambda runtime layers as sensitive code, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Establish a Peer Review Process:
    • Define a policy that mandates peer reviews for any changes to files named 'bootstrap' or runtime layers containing 'bootstrap'.
    • Implement a system in your version control platform (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket) that explicitly requires an "approval" label before merging code involving these sensitive components.
    • Ensure that reviewers are experienced in security practices and familiar with Lambda runtimes.
  2. Deploy Static Code Analysis Tools:
    • Integrate static analysis tools (e.g., Checkmarx, SonarQube) into the CI/CD pipeline.
    • Configure these tools to flag and fail builds when detected risky constructs such as:
      • curl, wget, or nc
      • Any usage of bash -c
      • Unchecked or blind network egress calls
    • Introduce an allowlist mechanism where risky constructs can only bypass checks if accompanied by a written, justified reason reviewed and approved by security teams.
  3. Restrict Bootstrap Role:
    • Verify that the 'bootstrap' file solely performs runtime initialization tasks and invokes the handler or Runtime Interface Client (RIC) as designed.
    • Apply rules to forbid any embedded persistence, telemetry beacons, or additional functionality within the 'bootstrap', unless explicitly approved through the peer-review process.
    • Audit the 'bootstrap' code periodically to ensure compliance with these restrictions.
  4. Enforce Pipeline-Only Deployment:
    • Block any direct uploads of Lambda runtime layers or the 'bootstrap' file via the AWS Management Console.
    • Configure permissions so that developers can only deploy changes through a CI/CD pipeline that enforces defined security checks.
    • Apply IAM policies to prevent unauthorized access to runtime layer modification workflows.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Official Documentation
  • AWS CodePipeline Documentation
  • AWS Security Blog

countermeasure.name: Enforce code-signed Lambda deployments with AWS Signer
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that only vetted code reaches production by pairing AWS Signer with a Lambda Code Signing Configuration (CSC): every deployment package must be signed with your approved signing profile before Lambda accepts it.

  1. Create a signing profile
    1. aws signer put-signing-profile \
       --profile-name prod-lambda-code \
       --platform-id AWSLambda-SHA384-ECDSA
  2. Store the profile ARN in your CI/CD secrets.
  3. Integrate signing into the pipeline
    • Package the ZIP or container image, then call aws signer start-signing-job (ZIP) or ECR image signing (container).
    • Fail the build if the signing job status isnt Succeeded.
  4. Define a Code Signing Configuration
    1. aws lambda create-code-signing-config \
       --allowed-publishers SigningProfileVersionArns=arn:aws:signer::profile/prod-lambda-code/* \
       --code-signing-policies UntrustedArtifactOnDeployment=Enforce
  5. Enforce blocks any unsigned or differently-signed artifact.
  6. Attach the CSC to functions
    1. aws lambda update-function-code-signing-config \
       --function-name orders-handler \
       --code-signing-config-arn arn:aws:lambda::code-signing-config:csc-abc123
  7. Include this step in all CloudFormation/Terraform modules so drift is impossible.
  8. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable the AWS Config rule lambda-function-code-signing-config-enabled to detect functions without a CSC.
    • Use EventBridge to alert when a deployment fails due to CodeSigningError, signalling a bypass attempt or pipeline mis-sign.
  9. Key hygiene
    • Rotate the Signer KMS key annually; update the signing profile to the new key version.
    • Restrict signer:StartSigningJob permission to the build role; deny it in production accounts via SCPs.

By requiring AWS-signed packages and enforcing CSCs, you shut the door on tampered artifacts, typo-squatted libraries, and shadow deployments.

References

  • Code signing for AWS Lambda
  • AWS Signer Developer Guide

countermeasure.name: Enforce tagging standards on Lambda functions
countermeasure.desc:
Every Lambda function must carry a complete, standardized tag set for example Environment, Owner, CostCenter, and Compliance so that security, cost-allocation, and automation workflows can rely on consistent metadata.

How to implement

  1. Define the mandatory keys in a central document (e.g., tagging-standard.md) and publish it to your IaC repository.
  2. Validate in the pipeline
    • Add a build step (cfn-lint/Checkov/GitHub Action, etc.) that fails if the template or aws lambda create-function command omits any required tag.
  3. Enforce at runtime with AWS Config
    • Enable the managed rule required-tags or deploy a custom rule that checks the AWS::Lambda::Function resource type and your mandatory tag list.
    • Configure the rule for continuous evaluation and send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket.
  4. Auto-remediate or quarantine
    • Attach an EventBridge rule to run an SSM Automation or Lambda fixer script that adds missing tagsor, in strict environments, disables the function until tags are corrected.
  5. Review quarterly
    • Spot-check tag accuracy (e.g., does the Owner tag still map to an active identity?) and update the standard when new reporting requirements appear.

Automated tagging enforcement guarantees that every Lambda function can be located, costed, and governed, while eliminating drift caused by manual provisioning.

References

  • Tagging Lambda functions
  • AWS Config rule required-tags

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with perfect-forward-secrecy for all Lambda traffic
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every network path that carries AWS Lambda control-plane or data-plane trafficCLI / SDK calls to the Lambda API, Function URLs, ALB/API Gateway invokes, VPC egress, and third-party integrationsnegotiates TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3 using PFS cipher suites (ECDHE or DHE). Disable legacy SSL/TLS versions and static-key ciphers to eliminate downgrade and session-key compromise risks.

Implementation guidance

  1. Runtime & library hardening
    • Use current AWS SDKs, AWS CLI v2, and OS packages (OpenSSL 1.1.1, Java 8 u181, .NET 4.6) that default to TLS 1.2+.
    • In container images or AMIs set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 and remove *_RSA_* suites from the cipher list.
  2. Outbound Lambda networking
    • When the function runs in a VPC, allow only TCP 443 to interface endpoints (S3, STS, Secrets Manager, etc.). Block port 80 in security groups and route tables.
    • For external calls, pin the destination to https:// URIs and verify certificates (e.g., with Python requests.verify=True).
  3. Inbound invoke paths
    • Function URLs: set AuthType=AWS_IAM or another auth method; TLS is auto-enforced by AWS but add a WAF rule that blocks any request with the X-Forwarded-Proto != https.
    • API Gateway / ALB: enable TLS 1.2 minimum on the custom domain or listener policy; prefer ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06.
    • For IoT or custom MQTT, use certificates that advertise only TLS 1.2/1.3 and EC cipher suites.
  4. Central guardrails
    • Attach an SCP that denies lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl or execute-api:Invoke when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy AWS Config rules or cfn-nag checks that fail if an ALB listener policy includes TLS 1.0/1.1 or if a VPC security group permits port 80 egress.
  5. Continuous verification
    • Add a CI test that attempts openssl s_client -connect lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 and expect failure; succeed with -tls1_2.
    • Scan AMIs and containers monthly with Inspector or OpenSCAP for outdated OpenSSL/LibreSSL versions.
  6. Incident response & patching
    • Subscribe to AWS Security Bulletins; redeploy all Lambda runtime layers when critical TLS CVEs are announced.
    • Rotate any function URL or API Gateway custom certificates that use deprecated algorithms (RSA-1024, SHA-1).

Following this control guarantees strong, modern encryption end-to-end, satisfying compliance frameworks and protecting Lambda workloads against passive interception and forward-decryption attacks.

References

  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum for all AWS service endpoints
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda security

countermeasure.name: Grant least-privilege IAM permissions to Lambda execution roles
countermeasure.desc:
Create a dedicated IAM role for every Lambda function and attach only the permissions the code truly needsnothing more, nothing wildcard.

  1. Inventory required actions
    • List each AWS API the function calls (e.g., dynamodb:PutItem, s3:GetObject, secretsmanager:GetSecretValue).
    • Add logs:CreateLogGroup, logs:CreateLogStream, and logs:PutLogEvents for basic logging if they arent provided by a shared policy.
  2. Author a scoped policy
    • Restrict Resource to exact ARNs (specific table, bucket prefix, secret) instead of *.
    • Where possible, add condition keysfor example dynamodb:LeadingKeys, s3:prefix, aws:SourceVpc, or tagbased conditions.
  3. Attach the policy to a unique execution role
    • Console: Configuration Permissions choose or create role.
    • IaC example (CloudFormation):
      • LambdaRole:
         Type: AWS::IAM::Role
         Properties:
           AssumeRolePolicyDocument:
             Statement:
               - Effect: Allow
                 Principal: Service: lambda.amazonaws.com
                 Action: sts:AssumeRole
           Policies:
             - PolicyName: OrdersFunctionPolicy
               PolicyDocument: {...}   # actions/resources from step 2
  4. Remove default privileges
    • Delete unused AWS-managed policies like AWSLambdaFullAccess.
    • Never attach AdministratorAccess or * actionsfail the pipeline if these appear.
  5. Continuous validation
    • Enable IAM Access Analyzer unused permissions and prune actions that havent been called for 90 days.
    • Deploy AWS Config rule iam-managed-policy-check or a cfn-nag/Checkov rule in CI to block wildcard actions or resources.
  6. Review regularly
    • Re-run Access Analyzer after each feature release.
    • Rotate any secrets or keys the function accesses, updating the role policy as needed.

Applying strict, role-specific policies limits blast radius, supports the principle of least privilege, and satisfies compliance auditors looking for excessive permissions.

References

  • Security best practices for AWS Lambda
  • IAM Access Analyzer

countermeasure.name: Isolate Lambda network traffic with locked-down VPC subnets and security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Run every Lambda function inside a dedicated set of private subnets and attach it to a least-privilege security group so the function can reach only the services it truly needsnothing else.

How to implement

  1. Create lambda-only private subnets
    • Place them in the application VPC but do not route them to an Internet Gateway.
    • If outbound internet access is required, send traffic through a shared NAT Gateway or a VPC endpoint (for S3, DynamoDB, etc.).
  2. Define a restrictive security group
    • Egress rules: allow only the ports and CIDRs (or other SGs) that correspond to your dependenciesfor example, TCP 5432 to an RDS SG, HTTPS (443) to a Secrets Manager VPC endpoint SG. Remove the default all traffic egress rule.
    • Ingress rules: normally none are required; Lambda creates connections out of the subnet. If the function must be called by an internal ALB, allow only that ALBs SG on the listener port.
  3. Attach the VPC config to the function
    1. aws lambda update-function-configuration \
       --function-name payment-handler \
       --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0aa123,subnet-0bb456 \
                   SecurityGroupIds=sg-0lambda
  4. Guardrails and drift detection
    • Add an AWS Config rule (or cfn-nag/Checkov policy) that fails if a Lambda SG allows 0.0.0.0/0 or if the subnet route table points to an Internet Gateway.
    • Monitor VPC Flow Logs for unexpected destinations; tighten SG rules when new patterns appear.
  5. Document and review
    • Keep subnet IDs and SG IDs in your IaC modules so every environment uses the same isolation model.
    • Re-evaluate access rules quarterly or whenever the functions dependencies change.

Locking Lambda functions into isolated subnets and SGs minimizes lateral movement, reduces the attack surface, and satisfies segmentation requirements without sacrificing performance.

References

  • Configuring a Lambda function to access VPC resources
  • AWS Lambda security best practices network isolation

countermeasure.name: Keep Lambda functions on supported runtimes
countermeasure.desc:
AWS periodically deprecates Lambda runtimes (Node .js, Python, Java, .NET, Ruby, Go). A function that keeps running on an out-of-support runtime no longer receives security patches, and AWS may block deployments after the end-of-life date.

Implementation guidance

  1. Baseline now list every function and its runtime:
    1. aws lambda list-functions --query 'Functions[*].[FunctionName,Runtime]' --output table

Flag anything marked deprecated in the [runtime support policy].

  1. Automate continuous checks
    • Enable the managed AWS Config rule lambda-function-running-supported-runtime (or a custom rule) so any function on an outdated runtime is immediately marked NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Forward Config notifications to an SNS topic tied to your ticketing system or ChatOps channel.
  2. Update promptly
    • Track AWS deprecation announcements; add the EOL date to your backlog.
    • Use feature branches to bump the runtime version in your IaC (SAM/CloudFormation/Terraform) and CI pipeline, run tests, then deploy.
    • For container images, rebuild from an up-to-date base image and push a new tag.
  3. Prevent drift
    • Add a pipeline gate that rejects any create-function or update-function-configuration call if the --runtime flag is not in your approved list.
    • For containers, scan the image in CodeBuild/CodePipeline with AWS Inspector or Trivy before deployment.
  4. Review quarterly
    Re-run the baseline script or a Config compliance report; remove any temporary suppression and schedule upgrades for newly announced EOL runtimes.

Keeping all functions on supported runtimes guarantees ongoing security patches, performance optimisations, and access to the latest Lambda features.

References

  • AWS Lambda runtimes supported versions and deprecation policy
  • AWS Config rule lambda-function-running-supported-runtime

countermeasure.name: Log all Lambda API activity with CloudTrail and secure S3 storage
countermeasure.desc:
Create an organization-wide, multi-Region CloudTrail trail that records every AWS Lambda management eventfunction creation, configuration updates, permission changes, InvokeFunction calls, and Function URL operationsand delivers the logs to a hardened S3 bucket for long-term retention and forensic search.

Implementation steps

  1. Enable a multi-Region trail
    • Console: CloudTrail Trails Create trail select Apply trail to all Regions and log Management events Read + Write (Lambda is covered automatically).
    • CLI / IaC example:
      • aws cloudtrail create-trail \
         --name org-lambda-trail \
         --s3-bucket-name org-trail-logs \
         --is-multi-region-trail
        aws cloudtrail start-logging --name org-lambda-trail
  2. Protect the S3 log bucket
    • Block public access and require TLS in the bucket policy:
      • "Condition": { "Bool": { "aws:SecureTransport": "false" } }
    • Enable SSE-KMS encryption with a customer-managed key; limit key-policy access to the CloudTrail service principal and your security team.
    • Turn on log file validation and bucket versioning to detect tampering.
  3. Retention & analytics
    • Apply lifecycle rules: e.g., keep logs in the S3 Standard tier for 90 days, then transition to Glacier Instant Retrieval or Deep Archive, deleting after seven years.
    • Optionally send the trail to CloudWatch Logs or Lake Formation for near-real-time detection and SQL-based hunting.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Deploy AWS Config rules such as cloudtrail-enabled and s3-bucket-server-side-encryption-enabled so any drift triggers alerts.
    • Create EventBridge rules that notify your on-call channel when someone issues StopLogging, DeleteTrail, or changes the bucket policy.
  5. Periodic review
    • Quarterly, confirm that new AWS Regions and new Lambda features are still captured, and rotate or disable unused KMS keys and IAM principals.
    • Validate integrity with aws cloudtrail validate-logs during tabletop or incident-response exercises.

Implementing centralized, secure CloudTrail logging for Lambda provides an immutable audit trail that supports compliance, incident response, and continuous improvement of your serverless security posture.

References

  • Logging AWS Lambda API calls with AWS CloudTrail
  • Best practices for CloudTrail log file integrity and S3 security

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

countermeasure.name: Monitor package hash and bootstrap integrity
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing robust security countermeasures for AWS Lambda custom runtimes involves the following steps:

  1. Record Approved CodeSha256:
    • For every deployment of AWS Lambda, compute the CodeSha256 hash of the deployed function package using the AWS CLI or SDK.
    • Maintain an allowlist of approved CodeSha256 hashes in a secure system, such as AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or a Configuration Management Database (CMDB) with audit logs enabled for modifications.
  2. Monitor Drift through EventBridge:
    • Create an EventBridge rule to capture UpdateFunctionCode events from CloudTrail. Configure CloudTrail to log all function updates to ensure full visibility of unplanned changes.
    • When an UpdateFunctionCode event is triggered, invoke a Lambda function or automation workflow that runs get-function against the affected Lambda function.
    • Compare the reported CodeSha256 from get-function output against the stored allowlist of approved hashes.
    • If a discrepancy is identified, create a high-severity finding and alert relevant teams immediately using an integrated mechanism such as AWS Security Hub or Amazon SNS.
  3. Verify Integrity During CI/CD:
    • In your CI/CD pipeline, compute and store a checksum for the bootstrap file (or its layer path) during the packaging step of Lambda custom runtimes.
    • For container-based runtimes, capture the digests of the container image and validate the ENTRYPOINT and CMD against the approved baselines stored during CI.
    • Post-deploy, verify the deployed checksums match the precomputed checksums from the CI/CD pipeline.
  4. Persist Integrity Metadata:
    • Store integrity metadata such as approved hashes, container digests, and runtime file checksums in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store, with secure access controls to limit modifications to authorized personnel or automation scripts.
    • Enable versioning and tagging for stored metadata to support audit trails and provide recovery options in case of accidental modifications.
  5. Detect Unauthorized Bootstrap Changes:
    • Ensure that bootstrap file integrity validation is part of runtime monitoring. Regularly automate hash comparisons and include mechanisms for detecting tampering during runtime or in transit.
    • Integrate findings from the above monitoring mechanisms into AWS Security Hub or a centralized incident management tool for triage and resolution.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda CodeSha256
  • Using CloudTrail with Amazon EventBridge
  • AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store
  • AWS Security Hub

countermeasure.name: Require AWS_IAM authentication on Lambda function URLs
countermeasure.desc:
When you expose an AWS Lambda function through a Function URL, set the AuthType to AWS_IAM so that every invoke request must be SigV4-signed by an IAM principal with an explicit allow on lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl. This prevents unauthenticated internet traffic from reaching the function and lets you apply fine-grained least-privilege policies, MFA enforcement, and session-duration limits.

Implementation steps

  1. Create or update the Function URL
    1. aws lambda create-function-url-config \
         --function-name orders-handler \
         --auth-type AWS_IAM \
         --cors AllowedOrigins=https://app.example.com
      #or
      aws lambda update-function-url-config \
         --function-name orders-handler \
         --auth-type AWS_IAM
  2. Authorize callers
    • Add an IAM policy that allows lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl on the function ARN with /url suffix:
      arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:123456789012:function:orders-handler:url
    • Scope the policy to trusted roles or users; require MFA or session tags if needed.
  3. Invoke securely
    • Clients must include an Authorization header with a SigV4 signature (aws4_request).
    • For browsers, front the URL with API Gateway or CloudFront signed cookies if you cant sign requests client-side.
  4. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Deploy an AWS Config rule or SCP that prevents AuthType: NONE in production accounts.
    • Stream Lambda access logs to CloudWatch; alert on 403 errors to detect unauthorized attempts.

Using AWS_IAM authentication ensures only vetted principals can reach the function, leveraging the full power of IAM policies and audit trails.

References

  • Using IAM authorization for Lambda function URLs
  • lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl permissions and examples

countermeasure.name: Require MFA for root and IAM users
countermeasure.desc:
Protect the AWS account against credential theft by enforcing multi-factor authentication (MFA) on the root user and every IAM user:

  1. Enable MFA devices
    • Root user: sign in as root and register a hardware key, FIDO2 passkey, or virtual TOTP device at Account Security credentials Multi-factor authentication.
    • IAM users: in the IAM console or CLI (aws iam enable-mfa-device), attach a virtual or hardware MFA device to each user. Automate user creation so MFA is required before console access is granted.
  2. Block sessions without MFA
    • Attach an IAM policy that denies all actions when aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent is false.
    • Apply an SCP at the OU or root level that prevents non-MFA console logins in production accounts.
  3. Monitor and enforce
    • Turn on AWS Config managed rules root-account-mfa-enabled and iam-user-mfa-enabled; alert when they report NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Stream CloudTrail to Security Hub and create findings if DeactivateMFADevice, DeleteVirtualMFADevice, or root logins without MFA occur.
  4. Operational hygiene
    • Register two MFA devices for the root user (primary and backup).
    • Review the IAM credential report monthly; disable or delete any user lacking MFA or with unused access keys.

Implementing mandatory MFA shuts down most credential-stuffing, phishing, and console-token replay attacks, forming the first and strongest line of defense for all Lambda-related and broader AWS operations.

References

  • Enable MFA for the root user
  • Using MFA with IAM users

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)

countermeasure.name: Restrict lambda resource-based policies to explicit principals
countermeasure.desc:
Whenever you add a resource-based policy to a Lambda function (e.g., when granting another AWS account, an AWS service, or an API Gateway permission to invoke it), list only the exact IAM principal ARNs or service principals that require access.
Do not use wildcard principals ("*"), anonymous principals, or broad AWS service wildcards ("lambda.amazonaws.com" without conditions). Wildcards expose the function to unintended callers and defeat least-privilege design.

implementation checklist

  1. author precise statements
    1. {
       "Effect": "Allow",
       "Principal": { "AWS": "arn:aws:iam::444455556666:role/PaymentService" },
       "Action": "lambda:InvokeFunction",
       "Resource": "arn:aws:lambda:us-east-1:111122223333:function:ProcessPayment"
      }
  2. Specify the consuming account ID and role name; for cross-account access, pair with aws:SourceArn and aws:SourceAccount condition keys.
  3. block wildcards in CI/CD
    • Add cfn-nag / Checkov / cfn-guard rules that fail a build if Principal equals "*" or if no Condition keys are present for an AWS service principal.
  4. continuous compliance
    • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-public-access-prohibited (or a custom rule) to detect policies with public or wildcard principals and mark them NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Subscribe Security Hub to forward findings to your on-call channel so unintended permissions are fixed immediately.
  5. review quarterly
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer to enumerate current function resource policies and highlight new external principals.
    • Remove any stale or unused permissions.

Adhering to explicit-principal policies limits who can invoke or manage your Lambda functions, sharply reducing the risk of unauthorized access or privilege escalation.

References

  • Controlling access with resource-based policies for Lambda
  • AWS Config managed rule

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1036 - Account Use Policies

countermeasure.name: Restrict UpdateFunctionCode and enforce immutable release flow
countermeasure.desc:
1. Restrict IAM permissions for Lambda updates:
    • Create or update IAM policies to restrict the lambda:UpdateFunctionCode and lambda:PublishVersion actions to a dedicated CI/CD principal.
    • Implement permission boundaries or Service Control Policies (SCPs) to enforce restrictions across accounts. Examples include denying human users access to these actions entirely in production environments.
    • Test the IAM policies with tools such as AWS IAM Access Analyzer to ensure that only the CI principal has access to these sensitive actions.
  2. Enforce code signing during deployment:
    • Enable and configure Lambda Code Signing by creating a code signing configuration (CSC) that includes trusted signing profiles.
    • Update deployment workflows to use the CSC. Add IAM conditions such as lambda:CodeSigningConfigArn to ensure that only signed artifacts can be deployed.
    • Use versions and aliases to promote changes instead of enabling direct edits:
      • Publish a new function version after deployment.
      • Update aliases to point explicitly to the new version.
  3. Disallow edits to the $LATEST version in production:
    • Disable direct updates to the $LATEST function version for production accounts using IAM policies.
    • Implement governance practices that require testing and approval in staging environments before updating versions or aliases in production.
  4. Establish integrity monitoring and alerts:
    • Enable AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config to track events related to Lambda code updates, especially UpdateFunctionCode and PublishVersion.
    • Create Amazon CloudWatch alarms or EventBridge rules for detecting unauthorized edits or direct code updates, both via the AWS Management Console and SDK.
    • Set up automated workflows to quarantine compromised functions:
      • Disable traffic to affected aliases if integrity verification fails.
      • Notify security teams for manual review and approval.
  5. Implement immutable and auditable CI/CD pipelines:
    • Design CI/CD workflows that ensure all artifacts deployed are code-signed and verified.
    • Adopt tools such as AWS CodePipeline or external pipelines like Jenkins, GitHub Actions, etc., to enforce versioning and signing practices.
    • Use version control systems and tags to establish traceable records for every production release.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Code Signing
  • IAM Permission Boundaries
  • Service Control Policies (SCPs)
  • AWS CodePipeline
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS CloudTrail

SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Use PrivateLink interface endpoints for Lambda and supporting services
countermeasure.desc:
Create interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for AWS Lambda and every service the function relies onLambda control plane (com.amazonaws.<region>.lambda), Function URLs (com.amazonaws.<region>.lambda-url), and supporting endpoints such as S3, ECR API/ECR DKR, CloudWatch Logs, KMS, DynamoDB, SQS, or Kinesisso that all deployment, invoke, and dependency traffic stays on the AWS backbone instead of the public internet.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet selection choose at least two private subnets in different Availability Zones to give Lambda enough ENIs for scaling and AZ-level resilience.
  2. Provision endpoints create each endpoint with the AWS CLI or IaC:
    1. aws ec2 create-vpc-endpoint \
         --vpc-id vpc-1234abcd \
         --service-name com.amazonaws.eu-west-1.lambda \
         --vpc-endpoint-type Interface \
         --subnet-ids subnet-a subnet-b \
         --security-group-ids sg-lambda-endpoints
  3. keep Private DNS enabled so the standard service hostname automatically resolves to the VPC-local IPs.
  4. Harden network access attach a security group that allows only TCP 443 from Lambda subnets or CI/CD hosts; block port 80 entirely.
  5. Apply endpoint policies restrict calls to the exact actions your workload needs (e.g., lambda:InvokeFunction, lambda:GetLayerVersion) and, if required, add aws:SourceVpce or aws:SourceVpc conditions for defense-in-depth.
  6. Lock function resource policies when using Function URLs or cross-account invokes, include StringEquals {"aws:SourceVpce":"vpce-"} so internet-sourced requests are rejected even if a public path exists.
  7. Validate from a private instance run dig lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com and confirm it returns a 10.x address; disable the NAT Gateway temporarily and verify that deployments and invokes still succeed.
  8. Monitor and audit enable VPC Flow Logs for the endpoint ENIs, set CloudWatch alarms on rejected flows, and add an AWS Config rule that flags production VPCs missing the Lambda endpoint.

PrivateLink keeps Lambda control-plane and data traffic inside AWS, reduces latency, simplifies firewall rules, and satisfies compliance mandates that prohibit internet egress for sensitive workloads.

References

  • Interface VPC endpoints (AWS PrivateLink) for Lambda
  • AWS PrivateLink basics and best practices

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped

SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Use temporary credentials via AWS STS
countermeasure.desc:
Give every Lambda function, service, CI/CD pipeline, and human operator an IAM role to assume rather than a static IAM user with access-key pairs. When a principal assumes the role, AWS Security Token Service (STS) hands back short-lived credentials (default 1 h) that AWS rotates automatically. This removes permanent secrets from code, cuts the blast radius of a leaked key, and lets you attach granular, least-privilege policies to each role.

Implementation steps

  1. Create purpose-built roles one per Lambda function (execution role) and one per developer or automation persona. Scope policies to the minimum actions and resources needed.
  2. Configure assumption paths
    • AWS services: add the service principal (e.g., lambda.amazonaws.com, codebuild.amazonaws.com) to the roles trust policy so it can call sts:AssumeRole.
    • Humans/federation: use IAM Identity Center, SAML, or OIDC to let users assume their role after MFA.
  3. Remove static keys disable or delete legacy IAM users and hard-coded keys; store only the role ARN in configuration.
  4. Set sensible session limits keep MaxSessionDuration low (15 min1 h for interactive work; 12 h for workloads).
  5. Monitor & audit enable CloudTrail and IAM Access Analyzer to track who assumes which role; alert on unexpected roles or unusually long sessions.

Adopting STS-based roles wipes out long-lived credentials, enforces just-in-time access, and aligns with AWS recommended security posture.

References

  • Temporary credentials with AWS STS
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda IAM roles

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: SingleAZ failure for VPC functions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions are placed in a VPC that spans only a single Availability Zone, an AZ outage (due to hardware failure, networking issues, or scheduled maintenance) renders those functions unable to access their ENIs, subnets, or dependent servicescausing complete service disruption.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • AWS Infrastructure Failures: Power, network, or hardware faults isolated to one AZ.
  • Misconfiguration: VPC subnet or NAT gateway deployment limited to a single AZ.
  • Capacity Events: AZspecific resource exhaustion (e.g., ENI limits reached) preventing new function attachments.

Impacts

  • Service Outage: Affected Lambdas cannot execute, disrupting APIs, event processing, or backend jobs.
  • Data Delays: Queues and streams back up, leading to timesensitive data loss or processing lag.
  • Operational Costs: Emergency redeployments or crossAZ workarounds consume engineering time and may incur extra charges.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Hardware Failure: A hardware fault knocks out networking in AZA; all Lambda functions in that singleAZ VPC lose ENI attachment and fail to process inbound events.
  2. NAT Gateway Capacity Spike: A DDoS flood targets the NAT gateway in the lone AZ, saturating its throughput; VPCbound Lambdas cant reach the internet for API calls.
  3. Planned AZ Maintenance: AWS schedules maintenance that briefly disables ENI provisioning in AZB; because all subnets reside there, no new Lambda invocations succeed until maintenance completes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Credential compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Credential compromise in AWS Lambda occurs when the secrets, API keys, or IAM credentials used by functions are exposed or stoleneither through code, environment variables, or execution contextallowing attackers to impersonate or control your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, automated bots, thirdparty library leaks, compromised CI/CD pipelines
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Embedding secrets (AWS keys, database passwords) in function code or plaintext environment variables
    • Retrieving IAM role tokens from the Lambda execution environment via SSRF or metadataendpoint exploits
    • Exposing credentials in version control systems, build artifacts, or CloudWatch logs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Function Invocation: Attackers invoke functions at will, potentially incurring costs or executing unwanted actions
  • Privilege Escalation & Lateral Movement: Stolen credentials grant access to other AWS services or higherprivilege roles
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by Lambdas (e.g., PII, business logic) can be read or modified
  • Service Disruption & Financial Loss: Illicit use of credentials can flood queues, trigger throttling, or bill for large-scale invocations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hardcoded Key Leak: A developer commits a Lambda function with embedded AWS keys to GitHub. An attacker clones the repo, uses the keys to read S3 buckets, and exfiltrates customer data.
  2. Metadata Endpoint Abuse: A malicious library loaded into the Lambda execution environment makes HTTP calls to the IMDS endpoint, harvesting the functions IAM role token and using it to spin up new EC2 instances.
  3. Log Exposure: A misconfigured logging library prints database credentials from environment variables to CloudWatch Logs; a compromised IAM principal with logs:GetLogEvents reads the logs and uses the credentials to drop the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1550.001 - Application Access Token

threat.name: Outdated runtime environments
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Outdated runtime environments occur when Lambda functions continue using deprecated or unpatched language runtimes (e.g. old Node.js, Python, Java versions), missing security fixes and performance improvements.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers scanning for known CVEs, supplychain adversaries embedding exploits in dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting publicly documented vulnerabilities in EOL runtimes.
    • Injecting malicious payloads through outdated library transitive dependencies.
    • Leveraging insecure default configurations tied to legacy runtimes.

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Attackers exploit CVEs to run arbitrary code in your functions.
  • Data Breach: Compromised functions expose sensitive input or environment data.
  • Service Disruption: Unpatched bugs cause function crashes or performance failures.
  • Compliance Risks: Use of unsupported runtimes may violate organizational or regulatory policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: A function running Python2.7 is targeted with a known bufferoverflow exploit, allowing an attacker to execute shell commands.
  2. Dependency Hijack: An outdated Node.js runtime pulls in a vulnerable version of a logging library; an attacker injects malicious code via crafted log messages.
  3. Misconfiguration Crash: A Java8 function uses an old JDBC driver with memoryleak bugs, causing repeated OOM errors and denial of service under load.

threat.name: Overly broad IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly broad IAM permissions occur when AWS Lambda execution roles or associated policies grant more privileges than necessaryoften using wildcards for actions or resourcesexposing your functions to escalate privileges or access unrelated services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised deployment pipelines, and external attackers using stolen credentials.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • IAM policies with "Action": "lambda:*" or "*" on "Resource": "*" attached to function roles.
    • Overpermissive trust relationships allowing any principal to assume the Lambda role.
    • Failure to apply leastprivilege when granting access to AWS services (S3, DynamoDB, IAM).

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Functions can call APIs beyond their scope (e.g., creating or deleting roles).
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive data from S3 buckets, databases, or Secrets Manager.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised functions pivot to other services or resources in your account.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended changes to infrastructure, such as spinning up expensive resources or deleting critical stacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Overreach: A Lambda role with s3:* on * is compromised; the attacker lists and downloads all buckets, harvesting PII.
  2. IAM Role Abuse: An overly broad iam:* permission lets a malicious function create a new admin user, granting full account control.
  3. Cost Shock: A function granted ec2:RunInstances and ec2:TerminateInstances is hijacked to spin up large fleets of instances, incurring massive charges and then deleting them to cover tracks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Lack of network isolation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda functions share flat or overly permissive network configurationssuch as residing in default VPC subnets without segmentation or securitygroup restrictionsthey gain unfettered access to internal systems and the internet, increasing risk of lateral movement and data exfiltration.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Compromised function code, malicious insiders, or thirdparty dependencies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting broad VPC subnet placement to reach databases, caches, or internal APIs.
    • Using SSRF or openredirect flaws within the function to pivot across network boundaries.
    • Leveraging unrestricted egress to exfiltrate data to attackercontrolled endpoints.

Impacts

  • Lateral Movement: Attackers breach internal resources (e.g., RDS, Redis) via the compromised functions network path.
  • Data Exfiltration: Sensitive payloads or environment variables are sent out over the internet.
  • Service Compromise: Unauthorized access to microservices, service meshes, or backend systems, undermining confidentiality and integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Database Pivot: A stolen function token is used to invoke a Lambda in the default VPC, which then connects to an internal MySQL cluster on port3306 to dump data.
  2. Internal Reconnaissance: An attacker injects SSRF payloads into a function endpoint, causing it to scan internal HTTP management interfaces and map out privileged services.
  3. Covert Exfiltration: A compromised dependency causes the function to upload decrypted S3 objects to an attackers external SFTP server, bypassing network ACLs.

threat.name: Lack of resource tagging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without consistent tagging, Lambda functions cant be programmatically identified for ownership, environment, or purposehindering cost tracking, security policy enforcement, and operational oversight.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, uncontrolled automation, and rogue deployments.
  • Vectors:
    • CI/CD pipelines creating functions without required Environment or Owner tags.
    • Manual console creations that omit security or compliance tags.
    • Thirdparty tooling that doesnt enforce tagging standards.

Impacts

  • Visibility Gaps: Security teams cant quickly locate or audit sensitive functions.
  • Policy Evasion: Tagbased IAM or GuardDuty suppression rules fail to apply, allowing unauthorized access.
  • Cost Overruns: Untracked orphan functions incur unexpected charges.
  • Cleanup Challenges: Hard to identify and decommission unused or outdated functions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Hidden Malicious Function: An attacker deploys a backdoor Lambda without Team or Project tagsescaping routine audits and persisting undetected.
  2. Policy Bypass: A compromised automation role creates a function lacking the Compliance=PCI tag, sidestepping strict IAM permissions tied to that tag.
  3. Orphaned Resources: A deprecated services Lambdas remain untagged; months later, they still run and bill but arent owned or monitored by any team.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data exposure at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data exposure at rest in AWS Lambda occurs when sensitive informationsuch as environment variables, function code packages, layers, or log snapshotsis stored unencrypted or with weak key management, making it accessible to unauthorized parties if storage systems are compromised.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised AWS credentials, and thirdparty service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Retrieving unencrypted Lambda environment variables or code bundles from S3/ECR.
    • Accessing /tmp storage on compromised execution hosts.
    • Downloading unencrypted CloudWatch log exports or Lambda layer artifacts.

Impacts

  • Secret Leakage: Exposed API keys, database passwords, or tokens.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of atrest encryption mandates (PCIDSS, HIPAA, GDPR).
  • Lateral Movement: Harvested credentials enable access to other AWS resources.
  • Reputational & Financial Damage: Data breach remediation costs and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. ECR Artifact Theft: An attacker with ECR read permissions pulls a Lambda image containing hardcoded secrets in its code, extracting them offline.
  2. S3 Snapshot Breach: Misconfigured S3 bucket hosts unencrypted function packages; adversaries download and inspect code to harvest environment variables.
  3. Log Export Exposure: A support engineer exports CloudWatch logs (including sensitive payloads) to an unencrypted S3 bucket, which is later accessed by unauthorized users.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Data interception in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data interception in transit occurs when communication to or from Lambda functionssuch as API Gateway requests, servicetoservice calls, or event payloadsis sent without proper TLS or through misconfigured network paths, allowing adversaries to eavesdrop on or alter the data stream.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, maninthemiddle attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Invoking Lambda over HTTP (API Gateway or Function URL) instead of HTTPS
    • Misconfigured VPC endpoints or transit gateways that dont enforce encryption
    • Disabling or improperly validating TLS in SDKs or custom HTTP clients

Impacts

  • Credential Theft: API keys, JWTs, or signed URLs in request headers can be captured
  • Payload Exposure: Sensitive event data (PII, business logic) is readable in flight
  • Message Tampering: Intransit modification of inputs or outputs leads to corrupted processing
  • Replay Attacks: Captured invocations can be resent to trigger unauthorized function executions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. API Gateway Misuse: A functions URL endpoint is configured for HTTP only. An attacker on the same network sniffs request bodies containing user credentials and session tokens.
  2. VPC Endpoint Bypass: Lambda communicates with an internal service through a VPC endpoint that doesnt require TLS. A compromised EC2 instance in the VPC intercepts and logs unencrypted RPC calls.
  3. TLS Downgrade in SDK: A custom Python client disables certificate verification when calling a Lambda-backed API; an attacker performs a MITM attack to inject malicious payloads into the functions execution.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unauthorized invocation via public resource policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Overly permissive Lambda resource policies (e.g. "Principal": "*") expose functions to anyone on the internet or any AWS account, allowing unauthorized parties to invoke them without credentials.

Threat Agents/ Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised thirdparty accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Resourcebased policies granting lambda:InvokeFunction to Principal: "*".
    • Crossaccount policies missing Condition: {"StringEquals": {"AWS:SourceAccount": ...}}.
    • Automated scanners discovering public ARNs and issuing invoke requests.

Impacts

  • Unauthenticated Execution: Attackers trigger functions at will, potentially running malicious logic.
  • Cost Overruns: Highvolume invocations rack up unexpected AWS charges.
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Functions that read or write sensitive data can be abused to leak or corrupt information.
  • Downstream Disruption: Flooded event sources (queues, streams) or dependent services may be overwhelmed or fail.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Function Flood: An attacker discovers a public Lambda ARN and scripts thousands of InvokeFunction calls per minute, incurring heavy costs and throttling backend resources.
  2. CrossAccount Abuse: A partners account has open invocation rights; a malicious actor uses it to invoke a paymentprocessing Lambda with crafted payloads, creating fraudulent transactions.
  3. Data Leak via Unauthorized Payloads: A function tied to an S3 bucket runs on every invocation; by invoking it with custom payloads, an attacker tricks it into returning sensitive file contents in its response.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of audit logging
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When Lambda API calls (e.g., CreateFunction, UpdateFunctionCode, InvokeFunction) arent captured by CloudTrail or centralized logging, unauthorized or malicious activity goes unrecorded.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious insiders or compromised roles making API calls
  • Automated tools invoking or updating functions without generating logs
  • Misconfigured CloudTrail trails or logdelivery failures

Impacts

  • Undetected Changes: Function code or configuration modifications arent noticed
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Incidents cant be reconstructed or attributed
  • Compliance Failures: Violation of auditlogging mandates (e.g., PCIDSS, HIPAA)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker updates a paymentprocessing Lambda to include malicious logic; without CloudTrail logs, the change isnt traced.
  2. A rogue script purges function versions via the SDK; absent audit entries, the deletions go unnoticed until failures occur.
  3. CloudTrail misconfiguration drops InvokeFunction records; a compromised role invokes backdoor functions repeatedly without alerting security teams.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Code integrity compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Malicious alteration of Lambda function code or its dependenciesvia compromised build pipelines, direct edits, or tainted layersinjects unauthorized logic into your serverless workloads.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised CI/CD systems, supplychain attackers
  • Vectors: Backdoored build artifacts, console/API code edits, inclusion of malicious Lambda layers

Impacts

  • Unauthorized code execution under your functions IAM role
  • Data exfiltration or tampering of event payloads and backend resources
  • Lateral movement via calls to other AWS services
  • Reputational harm and remediation costs

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CI/CD Injection: An attacker hijacks the build server to insert a reverseshell payload into the deployment ZIP.
  2. Console Swap: A compromised admin replaces production handler code via the AWS Console, embedding dataexfiltration logic.
  3. Malicious Layer: A popular thirdparty layer bundles a cryptominer, which executes under your account when included.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution

threat.name: Bootstrap backdoor persistence in custom runtimes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Custom runtimes in AWS Lambda rely on a 'bootstrap' file as their entry point, executed before reaching the handler. Without proper monitoring, this file can be manipulated to include malicious logic, enabling persistence across deployments.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers with access to deployment processes can modify the 'bootstrap' file to execute unauthorized activities, such as exfiltrating data, establishing backdoors, or altering runtime functionality.
Impacts
The compromise of the 'bootstrap' file can lead to unauthorized data access, persistent backdoors in the runtime environment, and stealthy modifications that evade detection during typical security reviews.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker with deployment privileges embeds malicious code into the 'bootstrap' file that exfiltrates sensitive data to an external server. Despite subsequent changes to the main handler logic, the hidden backdoor remains operational, continuing its activity undetected across multiple deployments.

reference.name: Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor (July 11, 2025)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1494 - Runtime Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Consider client-side encryption
countermeasure.desc:
We recommend that you plan your encryption strategy before implementing your table in DynamoDB. If you store sensitive or confidential data in DynamoDB, consider including client-side encryption in your plan. This way you can encrypt data as close as possible to its origin, and ensure its protection throughout its lifecycle. Encrypting your sensitive data in transit and at rest helps ensure that your plaintext data isnt available to any third party.

The AWS Database Encryption SDK for DynamoDB is a software library that helps you protect your table data before you send it to DynamoDB. It encrypts, signs, verifies, and decrypts your DynamoDB table items. You control which attributes are encrypted and signed.

reference.name: CWE-311: CWE-311

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Monitor DynamoDB operations using CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
CloudTrail can monitor both control plane events and data plane events. Control plane operations let you create and manage DynamoDB tables. They also let you work with indexes, streams, and other objects that are dependent on tables. Data plane operations let you perform create, read, update, and delete (also called CRUD) actions on data in a table. Some data plane operations also let you read data from a secondary index. To enable logging of data plane events in CloudTrail, you'll need to enable logging of data plane API activity in CloudTrail. See Logging data events for trails for more information.

When activity occurs in DynamoDB, that activity is recorded in a CloudTrail event along with other AWS service events in the event history. For more information, see Logging DynamoDB Operations by Using AWS CloudTrail. You can view, search, and download recent events in your AWS account. For more information, see Viewing Events with CloudTrail Event History in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

For an ongoing record of events in your AWS account, including events for DynamoDB, create a trail. A trail enables CloudTrail to deliver log files to an Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) bucket. By default, when you create a trail on the console, the trail applies to all AWS Regions. The trail logs events from all Regions in the AWS partition and delivers the log files to the S3 bucket that you specify. Additionally, you can configure other AWS services to further analyze and act upon the event data collected in CloudTrail logs.

reference.name: CWE-297: CWE-297

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Config to monitor configuration changes and ensure compliance with security policies
countermeasure.desc:
Using AWS Config, you can continuously monitor and record configuration changes of your AWS resources. You can also use AWS Config to inventory your AWS resources. When a change from a previous state is detected, an Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) notification can be delivered for you to review and take action. Follow the guidance in Setting Up AWS Config with the Console, ensuring that DynamoDB resource types are included.

You can configure AWS Config to stream configuration changes and notifications to an Amazon SNS topic. For example, when a resource is updated, you can get a notification sent to your email, so that you can view the changes. You can also be notified when AWS Config evaluates your custom or managed rules against your resources.

For an example, see Notifications that AWS Config Sends to an Amazon SNS topic in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB's encryption at rest to secure data stored in tables, backups, and streams
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB encrypts at rest all user data stored in tables, indexes, streams, and backups using encryption keys stored in AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS). This provides an additional layer of data protection by securing your data from unauthorized access to the underlying storage .

You can specify whether DynamoDB should use an AWS owned key (default encryption type), an AWS managed key, or a customer managed key to encrypt user data. For more information, see Amazon DynamoDB Encryption at Rest.

reference.name: CWE-311: CWE-311

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Use DynamoDB Streams to monitor data plane operations
countermeasure.desc:
DynamoDB is integrated with AWS Lambda so that you can create triggerspieces of code that automatically respond to events in DynamoDB Streams. With triggers, you can build applications that react to data modifications in DynamoDB tables.

If you enable DynamoDB Streams on a table, you can associate the stream Amazon Resource Name (ARN) with a Lambda function that you write. Immediately after an item in the table is modified, a new record appears in the table's stream. AWS Lambda polls the stream and invokes your Lambda function synchronously when it detects new stream records. The Lambda function can perform any actions that you specify, such as sending a notification or initiating a workflow.

For an example, see Tutorial: Using AWS Lambda with Amazon DynamoDB Streams. This example receives a DynamoDB event input, processes the messages that it contains, and writes some of the incoming event data to Amazon CloudWatch Logs.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM policy conditions for fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
When you grant permissions in DynamoDB, you can specify conditions that determine how a permissions policy takes effect. Implementing least privilege is key in reducing security risk and the impact that can result from errors or malicious intent.

You can specify conditions when granting permissions using an IAM policy. For example, you can do the following:

  • Grant permissions to allow users read-only access to certain items and attributes in a table or a secondary index.
  • Grant permissions to allow users write-only access to certain attributes in a table, based upon the identity of that user.

For more information, see Using IAM Policy Conditions for Fine-Grained Access Control.
