usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to CloudFront distribution
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to a CloudFront distribution occurs when an attacker gains access to the CloudFront distribution settings or content without proper authorization. This can lead to the manipulation of distribution settings, theft of sensitive data, or disruption of services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, unauthorized users.
  • Attack Vectors: Compromised AWS credentials, insufficient access controls, exposed API keys.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Unauthorized users may access or steal sensitive content.
  • Integrity: Attackers could modify distribution settings or content, leading to the distribution of malicious or incorrect information.
  • Availability: Attackers may disrupt services by altering or disabling the distribution.
  • Reputation: Loss of customer trust and potential legal consequences from data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker uses compromised AWS credentials to access and alter CloudFront settings, redirecting users to malicious content.
  2. Scenario 2: Insufficient access controls allow a former employee to log in and disrupt the CloudFront distribution, causing service outages.
  3. Scenario 3: An exposed API key is exploited to access CloudFront configurations, resulting in unauthorized changes to content delivery.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Data leakage through unencrypted data in transit
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data leakage occurs when sensitive information is transmitted over the network without encryption. In AWS CloudFront, this happens when data moves between edge locations, clients, or origin servers using insecure protocols like HTTP, making it vulnerable to interception.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, state-sponsored actors, competitors.
  • Attack Vectors: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, packet sniffing, compromised network infrastructure.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data like login credentials and personal information.
  • Integrity: Potential alteration of data in transit.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand trust and legal repercussions.
  • Financial Loss: Regulatory fines, litigation costs, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker intercepts unencrypted HTTP traffic on public Wi-Fi to steal user credentials.
  2. Scenario 2: Unencrypted software updates are intercepted and maliciously altered.
  3. Scenario 3: A state-sponsored actor intercepts unencrypted corporate data, leading to espionage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1032 - Standard Cryptographic Protocol

threat.name: Misconfigured CloudFront distributions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description Misconfigured CloudFront distributions can lead to serious security vulnerabilities, such as unauthorized access, data exposure, or service disruptions. These misconfigurations may include improper access settings, insecure SSL/TLS configurations, or incorrect origin server permissions, making the distribution susceptible to attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, careless administrators.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of public S3 buckets, unauthorized access to CloudFront distributions, insecure SSL/TLS settings.

Impacts

  • Confidentiality: Exposure of sensitive data to unauthorized users.
  • Integrity: Potential modification of data served by CloudFront.
  • Availability: Disruptions in service or unintended public access to private content.
  • Reputation: Damage to brand image due to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An S3 bucket linked to CloudFront is left publicly accessible, allowing attackers to download sensitive files.
  2. Scenario 2: A misconfigured SSL/TLS setting allows attackers to perform a MitM attack, intercepting data between the client and CloudFront.
  3. Scenario 3: Origin server permissions are too broad, allowing unauthorized users to alter content served by CloudFront.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Content tampering
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Content tampering occurs when an attacker alters the content delivered through a CloudFront distribution. This can involve modifying or injecting malicious code, defacing web pages, or changing the data served to end-users. Such tampering can lead to a variety of harmful outcomes, including the distribution of malware, misinformation, or unauthorized data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in origin servers, unauthorized access to CloudFront configurations, man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Impacts

  • Integrity: Altered content can mislead users, distribute malware, or damage trust.
  • Reputation: Users may lose trust in the organization due to the distribution of tampered or harmful content.
  • Legal and Compliance: Organizations may face legal action or fines if tampered content results in harm to users or violates regulations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Scenario 1: An attacker gains unauthorized access to the origin server and modifies the web application files, causing users to download malware.
  2. Scenario 2: A hacker intercepts and alters data being transmitted from the origin to CloudFront, leading to the delivery of defaced or misleading content.
  3. Scenario 3: A malicious insider modifies content on an origin server that is distributed via CloudFront, resulting in the display of unauthorized or offensive material.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1492 - Stored Data Manipulation

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-613
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-613: Insufficient Session Expiration According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."

countermeasure.name: Apply fine-grained identity policies
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure precise control over user access to resources, implement fine-grained identity policies using AWS Cognito. This approach involves creating specific IAM policies that tightly control what authenticated and unauthenticated users can access.

Begin by defining user roles and associating them with appropriate IAM policies. For instance, authenticated users might have policies granting them access to user-specific resources, whereas unauthenticated users might have restricted access.

Here's a step-by-step guide for a cloud engineer:

  1. Create an IAM Role for Authenticated Users
    • Navigate to the IAM console and create a new role for authenticated users.
    • Attach a policy to this role that grants permissions to access only specific resources. Use JSON policy documents for greater precision. Refer to the Cognito IAM roles documentation for example policies.
  2. Create an IAM Role for Unauthenticated Users
    • Similarly, create another role for unauthenticated users, ensuring the policy attached to this role is more restrictive.
  3. Associate Roles with Cognito Identity Pool
    • Navigate to the Cognito console and choose your identity pool.
    • Edit the identity pool settings to assign the roles created above to authenticated and unauthenticated users respectively.
  4. Test the Policies
    • Validate that authenticated users have the correct level of access and that unauthenticated users are appropriately restricted.

For more detailed information, refer to the AWS Cognito security guidelines and specific references on IAM roles.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of user accounts in AWS Cognito, it is highly recommended to enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA). By integrating MFA, an additional layer of protection is provided, reducing the risk of unauthorized access. Follow the guidelines below to implement MFA for your Cognito user pool:

  1. Log in to the AWS Management Console and navigate to the Amazon Cognito service.
  2. Select the user pool for which you want to enable MFA.
  3. In the left-hand navigation pane, choose MFA and verifications.
  4. Under the Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) section, configure your desired MFA settings:
    • Set the MFA status to Optional or Required based on your security needs.
    • Select the MFA methods you wish to enable, such as SMS or TOTP (Time-based One-Time Password).
  5. Configure the SMS or TOTP settings accordingly. For SMS, ensure you have an appropriate SMS role with sufficient permissions. For TOTP, users will need to register their compatible authenticator application.
  6. Save the changes to the user pool settings.

Following these steps will significantly enhance the security posture of your user accounts by leveraging MFA. For further information on configuring MFA with AWS Cognito, refer to the official documentation: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) in Amazon Cognito.

Additional detailed security considerations can be explored in the AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to sensitive user attributes
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing access control for sensitive user attributes in AWS Cognito is essential to enhance security and ensure that such attributes are only accessible by authorized users or services. Follow these guidelines to appropriately restrict access:

Step-by-Step Implementation:

  1. Define Sensitive User Attributes: Identify and label sensitive user attributes in your user pool. These could include PII (Personally Identifiable Information) such as email addresses, phone numbers, or any custom attributes that hold sensitive information.
  2. Configure User Pool Policies: Utilize Amazon Cognitos user pool settings to specify which attributes are sensitive and should have restricted access. This can be configured in the user pool attributes settings.
  3. Leverage IAM Policies: Create and enforce IAM policies for the roles and users accessing the user pool. Ensure that these policies adhere to the principle of least privilege, granting the minimum required permissions to access necessary attributes. More details on setting up secure policies can be found in the IAM policy examples.
  4. Use Amazon Cognito Contextual Data: Implement the use of contextual information (such as IP addresses, device types, etc.) to enhance security conditions under which an attribute can be accessed or modified. This approach helps mitigate unauthorized access from unexpected locations or devices.
  5. Audit and Monitor Access: Regularly audit and monitor access to sensitive user attributes using Amazon CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail. Enable logging and set up alerts for any suspicious or unauthorized access attempts. Refer to the Cognito Streams documentation for guidance on setting up logging and monitoring.
  6. Implement Encryption: Ensure that sensitive user attributes are encrypted both in transit and at rest. AWS Cognito provides built-in encryption for user data at rest, but ensure that transport layer encryption such as TLS is configured correctly for your user pool endpoints. More information can be found in the encryption documentation.

By following these steps and utilizing the features provided by AWS Cognito, cloud engineers can effectively limit access to sensitive user attributes, ensuring that only authorized users or services can access this information. For comprehensive security practices and guidelines, refer to the AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Set up proper session validity periods
countermeasure.desc:
To configure appropriate session validity periods and refresh token policies in AWS Cognito and thereby minimize the window of opportunity for session-based attacks, a cloud engineer should follow these steps:

  • Set Appropriate Session Timeout:

To mitigate potential session-based attacks, it is crucial to configure appropriate session timeout settings. AWS Cognito allows you to set the session duration through the app client settings. Navigate to the AWS Cognito console, select your user pool, and go to the "App clients" settings. Here, configure the Refresh Token Expiration and Token Expiration values to an appropriate timeframe based on your security requirements.

Refer to the following documentation for detailed instructions: AWS Cognito Token Endpoint Documentation.

  • Implement Refresh Token Rotation:

For enhanced security, implement a refresh token rotation policy. This means generating a new refresh token every time the refresh operation is performed. AWS Cognito supports refresh token rotation to further minimize the window in which a stolen token could be used. In the AWS Cognito console, under your user pool settings, enable the PreventUserExistenceErrors option, and configure the refresh token rotation as needed.

For more details, refer to the official security documentation: AWS Cognito Security Best Practices.

  • Regularly Review and Update Policies:

Frequently audit and update your session validity periods and refresh token policies to ensure they align with current security best practices and the evolving threat landscape. This proactive approach helps to continually minimize potential attack vectors.

Consult the following official resource for guidance: AWS Cognito Security Best Practices.

By carefully configuring session validity periods and refresh token policies following AWS Cognito security guidelines, you can significantly reduce the risk of session-based attacks on your applications.

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1035 - Limit Access to Resource Over Network

countermeasure.name: Validate JWT tokens
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the proper validation of JWT tokens and confirm their authenticity and integrity, cloud engineers should implement the following countermeasures based on the official AWS Cognito documentation:

1. Verify the Signature: AWS Cognito issues JWT tokens that are signed using a key. To verify the signature, you must use the JSON Web Key Set (JWKS) provided by AWS Cognito. Retrieve the JWKS from the provided URL and use it to validate the token's signature. Reference: AWS Cognito - Verifying a JSON Web Token.

2. Check the Token Expiration: Inspect the "exp" claim in the JWT to ensure that the token has not expired. This check prevents the use of tokens past their validity period, mitigating the risk of replay attacks. Reference for security measures: AWS Cognito Security.

3. Validate the Audience (aud) Claim: The "aud" claim should match the expected audience value configured in your application. This ensures that the token was issued for your specific application and not an unintended audience. Reference: AWS Cognito Security Documentation.

4. Verify the Issuer (iss) Claim: Ensure that the "iss" claim matches the expected issuer URL for your AWS Cognito user pool. This confirms that the token was issued by your trusted user pool. Reference: Verifying a JWT - AWS Cognito.

5. Validate the Token Claims: In addition to the above claims, validate any other token claims that your application relies on for authorization, such as "sub" for user ID and custom claims included in the token. Reference: Security guidelines for AWS Cognito.

6. Regularly Update Your JWKS: AWS rotates the signing keys periodically. Ensure your implementation can handle key rotation by regularly fetching the JWKS and updating your verification mechanisms accordingly. Reference: Using and Verifying Tokens.

By following these guidelines, cloud engineers can robustly validate JWT tokens, ensuring their authenticity and integrity, and thereby significantly enhance the security posture of applications leveraging AWS Cognito.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inadequate authorization controls
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured authorization policies can allow users to gain access to resources they should not have access to, potentially leading to data manipulation or leakage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders exploiting weak or misconfigured authorization policies to gain access to sensitive data or resources illegally.
Impacts
Data breach, unauthorized data modification, loss of data integrity, and potential legal and financial repercussions for failing to protect sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers a misconfiguration in AWS Cognito authorization policies that grant excessive permissions. By exploiting this, they access confidential customer data, modify records, and exfiltrate sensitive information, leading to significant harm to the organization's reputation and financial standing.

threat.name: Data exposure due to misconfigured tokens
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper management of tokens can lead to exposure of sensitive information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
External attackers, malicious insiders, or compromised applications can intercept or misuse improperly managed tokens.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to user accounts, unauthorized actions within user contexts, and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts a token transmitted over an insecure channel and uses it to gain unauthorized access to a user account. Alternatively, an insider with access to token storage leverages the token to perform unauthorized actions within the application.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

threat.name: Exposed user attributes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured user attribute policies can lead to exposure of sensitive personal information.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may exploit misconfigurations in user attribute policies to access, alter, or extract sensitive information stored within AWS Cognito.
Impacts
This can result in unauthorized access to PII (Personally Identifiable Information), leading to privacy violations, data breaches, and potential financial and reputational damage to the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers that email addresses and phone numbers are set to be publicly readable in the User Pool. By leveraging this misconfiguration, they can harvest this sensitive information for phishing attacks or identity theft. Another scenario might involve an insider modifying attribute policies to expose additional sensitive attributes without proper authorization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Compromised accounts due to poor multi-factor authentication (MFA)
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without multi-factor authentication (MFA), accounts become susceptible to unauthorized access if credentials are phished or otherwise compromised.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can use phishing schemes, social engineering tactics, or exploit credential leaks from other breaches to gain access to an account.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, and potentially damaging modifications or deletions of user data and application settings.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully phishes an AWS Cognito user's credentials through a convincing email. Without MFA in place, the attacker uses the compromised credentials to log in and access the account, leading to unauthorized data access and potential exploitation of the user's information.

threat.name: Insufficient session management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Poor session management can lead to session hijacking or replay attacks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit poorly managed sessions, particularly if session identifiers are predictable, not rotated frequently, or not securely stored.
Impacts
Successful exploitation can result in unauthorized access to user accounts, data breaches, and potential financial loss, damaging the companys reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker captures a user's session token through a man-in-the-middle attack or by accessing logs where tokens are stored improperly. The attacker then uses the token to impersonate the user and gain unauthorized access to sensitive resources.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Enable data encryption at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that data stored in AWS QuickSight is encrypted using AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS), follow these steps:

  1. Access the AWS Management Console and open the QuickSight console at https://quicksight.aws.amazon.com/.
  2. Navigate to the Account Settings.
  3. Scroll down to the Encryption section.
  4. In the Encryption Key dropdown, select AWS Key Management Service (KMS).
  5. Select an existing KMS key from the list or create a new KMS key by navigating to the AWS KMS Console.
  6. Ensure the chosen KMS key has the necessary permissions for QuickSight to use it for encrypting data at rest. This typically includes the kms:Encrypt, kms:Decrypt, kms:GenerateDataKey, and kms:DescribeKey actions.
  7. Save the settings to apply the KMS key for encrypting data at rest in QuickSight.

Encryption at rest for QuickSight ensures that your sensitive data is protected using strong cryptographic methods provided by AWS KMS, assisting in safeguarding the data against unauthorized access. For more detailed information, refer to the official documentation on Data Encryption at Rest.

Additionally, review the guidelines on the AWS QuickSight Security Documentation for comprehensive security practices and compliance requirements.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Restrict the functionality that people can access in Amazon QuickSight
countermeasure.desc:
When defining permissions for users in AWS QuickSight, it is crucial to ensure that each user has access only to the data and functionalities necessary for their roles. This minimizes security risks and adheres to the principle of least privilege. Follow these steps to implement accurate permissions:

  1. Identify and categorize user roles: Determine the various roles within your organization (e.g., data analyst, business user) and categorize them based on their data access and functionality requirements.
  2. Use AWS IAM for user management: AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) allows the creation of users, groups, and roles with specific permissions. Assign users to appropriate IAM groups or roles based on their category.
  3. Set up QuickSight-specific permissions: In QuickSight, ensure that permissions are granted at a granular level using predefined and custom permissions. Refer to the detailed guidance on customizing permissions in the QuickSight Console: Customizing Permissions to the QuickSight Console.
  4. Utilize resource-based policies: For shared resources such as dashboards, datasets, and analyses, apply resource-based policies to control access. This enhances security by specifying which users or groups can access particular resources.
  5. Regularly review and audit permissions: Conduct periodic reviews of user permissions to ensure they remain aligned with current role requirements. This includes checking for unnecessary privileges and adjusting access levels accordingly.

For a comprehensive understanding and additional best practices, please review the official AWS QuickSight security guidelines: AWS QuickSight Security Documentation.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Use Amazon QuickSight Enterprise edition
countermeasure.desc:
Adopting the Amazon QuickSight Enterprise edition allows your organization to leverage advanced security features, ensuring robust protection for your analytics data. Follow these guidelines to implement the countermeasure effectively:

  • Encryption at Rest and In Transit: Enable encryption features to protect data both at rest and in transit. QuickSight provides the ability to use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) Customer-Managed Keys (CMKs) for encryption, which allows you to have stringent control over the encryption and decryption processes.
  • Fine-Grained Access Control: Utilize QuickSights integration with AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to enforce fine-grained access controls. By defining IAM policies, you can control access based on the principles of least privilege, allowing users to perform only the tasks necessary for their job roles.
  • Integration with AWS CloudTrail for Auditing and Monitoring: Enable AWS CloudTrail to capture all API calls made within your QuickSight environment. This integration helps you maintain comprehensive logs for auditing purposes, monitor access patterns, and detect any anomalous activities effectively.

To implement these advanced security features, the following steps can be followed:

  1. Choose the QuickSight Enterprise edition during the subscription process. This edition offers the enhanced security capabilities necessary for meeting stringent security requirements.
  2. Configure encryption settings by visiting the QuickSight settings page and ensuring that data encryption is enabled using AWS KMS managed CMKs. Refer to the official documentation on Encrypting Data in Amazon QuickSight.
  3. Set up IAM policies to manage permissions for QuickSight users and resources. Detailed guidance on setting up IAM policies for QuickSight can be found in the IAM Policies for Amazon QuickSight section.
  4. Enable AWS CloudTrail logging for your AWS account. This setup ensures that all QuickSight API calls are recorded. Detailed steps for configuring CloudTrail can be followed from Logging Amazon QuickSight API Calls with AWS CloudTrail.

For more detailed security guidelines and recommendations, please refer to the Amazon QuickSight Security Documentation.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention
SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Use service control policies (SCPs) to restrict sign-up
countermeasure.desc:
To enforce strict control over who can sign up for Amazon QuickSight within your organization, implement Service Control Policies (SCPs) that specifically manage this access. These policies are vital in ensuring that only authorized personnel can access QuickSight, thereby reducing the risk of unauthorized data exposure. Follow the guidelines below to set up these SCPs:

  1. Create an SCP to Deny QuickSight Signup: Start by defining a policy that explicitly denies the quicksight:CreateAccountSubscription action. This will ensure that only users who are explicitly allowed can sign up for QuickSight.

  2. Attach the SCP to the Appropriate Organizational Unit (OU): Attach the SCP to your root organization or the specific OUs and accounts where you want to enforce this restriction. This prevents any users in these units from creating QuickSight accounts unless exceptions are made.

  3. Create Exceptions for Authorized Personnel: To allow specific users or roles to sign up for QuickSight, you can create an Allow SCP. This policy should be attached at a lower level (e.g., the individual account) to override the deny policy for these users.

  4. Test and Validate: Ensure that the policies are working as expected by attempting to create a QuickSight account with both authorized and unauthorized users. Validate that unauthorized users receive an Access Denied message and authorized users do not face any restrictions.

For detailed instructions and examples on how to create and manage Service Control Policies, refer to the official documentation: AWS QuickSight Security - SCPs.

Additional safeguarding measures and information regarding QuickSight account management can be found in the AWS QuickSight Security Guidelines.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Improper account management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper control over who can sign up for Amazon QuickSight can lead to unauthorized access and potential misuse of the service.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or attackers exploiting inadequate sign-up restrictions to gain access to the Amazon QuickSight environment.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, data leaks, potential data manipulation, and increased risk of security breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An individual registers for Amazon QuickSight using an unauthorized email or identity and gains access to sensitive organizational data, which they can then manipulate, expose, or steal.

threat.name: Unauthorized access or excessive permissions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without appropriate restrictions on the functionality that users can access in Amazon QuickSight, unauthorized users could gain access to sensitive data or perform actions they are not permitted to, leading to potential data breaches and business risks.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, either internal or external, can exploit the lack of restrictions by manipulating permissions or roles within Amazon QuickSight.
Impacts
Potential data breaches where sensitive business information is exposed, unauthorized modification or deletion of critical data, and significant business risks including operational disruption and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An employee with insufficient clearance manages to elevate their privileges and accesses confidential financial reports. An external attacker exploits a misconfigured or overly permissive role to extract sensitive customer data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insufficient encryption of stored data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data at rest that is not properly encrypted can be vulnerable to unauthorized access, leading to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, cybercriminals, and unauthorized third parties exploiting weak or absent encryption mechanisms.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, data breaches, loss of sensitive information, legal and compliance repercussions, and financial loss.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a cloud storage service where sensitive customer information is stored without proper encryption. The attacker extracts customer details and sells the information on the dark web, causing significant harm to the customer and the organizations reputation.

threat.name: Insufficient security measures
threat.desc:
General threat description
Using the basic version of AWS QuickSight can lead to insufficient security measures, as it does not include the advanced security features required to protect sensitive information effectively.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or internal users exploiting the lack of robust security features in the basic edition of QuickSight to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data.
Impacts
Potential exposure of confidential data, leading to data breaches, financial losses, reputational damage, and potential non-compliance with data protection regulations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker deliberately targeting an organization using the standard edition of QuickSight, successfully accessing sensitive analytics data due to weaker security controls. Another scenario could be an internal user accidentally exposing confidential information because the basic version does not provide the necessary security protocols to prevent such leaks.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure CloudWatch alarms for unusual activity in AWS Secrets Manager
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS Secrets Manager, set up AWS CloudWatch alarms to monitor and alert on any unusual activity or access patterns. This involves configuring CloudWatch metrics and creating alarms for specific actions that could indicate potential security incidents. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Enable CloudTrail Logging: Ensure AWS CloudTrail is enabled to log all API calls to AWS Secrets Manager.
  2. Define Key Metrics: Identify critical metrics to monitor, such as:
    • GetSecretValue
    • PutSecretValue
    • DeleteSecret
  3. Set Thresholds: Establish thresholds for these metrics that would indicate abnormal activity, such as a high frequency of secret retrievals or deletions.
  4. Create Alarms: In AWS CloudWatch, create alarms for these metrics. Configure them to trigger notifications if thresholds are exceeded.
  5. Configure Notifications: Set up AWS SNS (Simple Notification Service) to send alerts to designated personnel or systems in real-time.
  6. Regular Review: Periodically review and update the metrics, thresholds, and alarm configurations to ensure they remain effective and relevant.

reference.name: Security in AWS Secrets Manager

countermeasure.name: Enable automatic secret rotation in AWS Secrets Manager
countermeasure.desc:
To minimize the risk of unauthorized access due to stale or compromised secrets, configure AWS Secrets Manager to automatically rotate secrets at regular intervals. This ensures that secrets are periodically updated, reducing the likelihood of them being exploited by malicious actors. Follow these steps to implement automatic secret rotation:

Enable Secret Rotation:

  • Go to the AWS Secrets Manager console.
  • Select the secret you want to enable rotation for.
  • Click on "Rotate secret".

Define Rotation Schedule:

  • Choose a predefined schedule or specify a custom rotation interval (e.g., every 30 days). Use cron expressions for more granular control if needed.

Create a Lambda Function:

  • Develop an AWS Lambda function that handles the rotation logic. This function should:
    • Retrieve the current secret.
    • Generate a new version of the secret.
    • Update the secret in the relevant service or application.
    • Test the new secret to ensure it works correctly.
  • AWS provides sample Lambda functions for different use cases that can be customized to fit your requirements.

Attach the Lambda Function to the Secret:

  • In the rotation configuration, specify the ARN of the Lambda function that you created.
  • Configure the Lambda execution role with appropriate permissions to read and update the secret, as well as to update the application using the secret.

Test the Rotation Configuration:

  • Manually trigger a rotation to ensure that the Lambda function executes correctly and the secret updates without issues.
  • Monitor the logs and verify that the new secret is functioning as expected in the application.

reference.name: Rotate AWS Secrets Manager secrets

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2 or higher for AWS Secrets Manager communications
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data in transit and ensure the security of sensitive information, configure AWS Secrets Manager to use TLS 1.2 or higher for all communications. This ensures that data exchanged between AWS Secrets Manager and its clients is encrypted and secure from interception or tampering by unauthorized entities. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Verify TLS Configuration:

  • Ensure that all endpoints communicating with AWS Secrets Manager are configured to use TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • AWS Secrets Manager supports TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3 by default for all API operations.

Update Client Applications:

  • Ensure that all client applications interacting with AWS Secrets Manager are updated to support TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • Update libraries and SDKs used by your applications to their latest versions, as they often include improved security features and support for modern TLS protocols.

Enforce TLS in Application Code:

  • Modify your application code to explicitly require TLS 1.2 or higher for connections to AWS Secrets Manager.
  • For example, in Python, use the botocore library which supports TLS 1.2 by default
  • In Java, ensure that the JVM is configured to use TLS 1.2 or higher:

Configure Network Settings:

  • Use security groups and network ACLs to restrict traffic to only those endpoints that support TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • Ensure that load balancers, proxies, and other network devices are configured to enforce TLS 1.2 or higher for inbound and outbound traffic.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config to monitor API calls and verify that all communications with AWS Secrets Manager are using the appropriate TLS version.
  • Set up CloudWatch Alarms to detect and alert on any communications that do not comply with the TLS 1.2 or higher requirement.

reference.name: Security in AWS Secrets Manager

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Log all API calls to AWS Secrets Manager with AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
To enable comprehensive tracking and auditing of all user activities in AWS Secrets Manager, set up AWS CloudTrail to log all API calls. This helps in monitoring access patterns, detecting unauthorized actions, and maintaining an audit trail for compliance purposes. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Enable CloudTrail in Your AWS Account: Ensure that AWS CloudTrail is enabled in the AWS region where your AWS Secrets Manager is deployed.

  • Go to the AWS CloudTrail console.
  • If you do not have a trail, create a new one by clicking "Create trail."
  • Configure the trail to apply to all regions for comprehensive coverage.

Configure Logging for All API Calls: Ensure that the CloudTrail configuration includes logging for all API calls to AWS Secrets Manager.

  • In the trail settings, enable management and data events logging.
  • Include the AWS Secrets Manager service in the data events to capture all API interactions.

Store Logs in a Secure S3 Bucket: Designate an Amazon S3 bucket to store CloudTrail logs securely.

  • Ensure the S3 bucket has appropriate access policies to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Enable server-side encryption for log files stored in the S3 bucket.

Set Up Log Validation and Integrity Checks: Enable log file validation in CloudTrail to ensure the integrity of the log files.

  • This helps in detecting any tampering of log data.

Monitor and Analyze Logs: Use AWS CloudWatch Logs to monitor and analyze the logs generated by CloudTrail.

  • Set up CloudWatch log groups and streams to collect and store CloudTrail logs.
  • Create metrics and alarms to detect unusual activities or patterns indicating potential security issues.

reference.name: What Is AWS CloudTrail?

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

countermeasure.name: Maintain privacy and security of traffic to AWS Secrets Manager using private network routes
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the privacy and security of traffic to AWS Secrets Manager, use private network routes such as AWS PrivateLink, VPN, or AWS Direct Connect. These methods help isolate traffic from the public internet, reducing the risk of interception and unauthorized access. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Set Up AWS PrivateLink:

  • Create an Interface VPC Endpoint:
    • Open the Amazon VPC console.
    • In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints" and then "Create Endpoint."
    • Select "AWS Services" and choose "com.amazonaws.<region>.secretsmanager" from the service name list.
    • Select the VPC in which to create the endpoint.
    • Choose the subnets and security groups that will allow access to the endpoint.
  • Configure DNS:
    • Ensure that "Enable DNS name" is selected to allow private DNS resolution within your VPC.
  • Update Security Groups:
    • Modify the security groups associated with your resources to allow traffic from the VPC endpoint.

Set Up AWS Site-to-Site VPN:

  • Create a VPN Connection:
    • Open the Amazon VPC console.
    • In the navigation pane, choose "VPN Connections" and then "Create VPN Connection."
    • Configure the customer gateway and virtual private gateway settings.
    • Once the VPN connection is created, configure your on-premises router with the provided configuration details.
  • Establish the VPN Tunnel:
    • Ensure the VPN tunnels are up and that traffic is routing through the VPN connection.
  • Update Routing Tables:
    • Update the route tables in your VPC to direct traffic destined for AWS Secrets Manager through the VPN connection.

Set Up AWS Direct Connect:

  • Create a Direct Connect Connection:
    • Open the AWS Direct Connect console.
    • Choose "Create Connection" and select the appropriate location and port speed.
    • Once the connection is provisioned, set up the Direct Connect gateway and virtual interfaces (VIFs) to connect to your VPC.
  • Configure Network Routing:
    • Update your network routing to ensure that traffic to AWS Secrets Manager uses the Direct Connect path.

Configure Security Groups and Network ACLs:

  • Ensure that security groups and network ACLs are configured to allow traffic only from your private network routes (VPC endpoints, VPN connections, or Direct Connect).
  • Implement least privilege principles to restrict access only to necessary resources.

reference.name: What is Amazon VPC?

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)

countermeasure.name: Prevent logging of sensitive commands in command shells
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard sensitive information from being inadvertently stored in command history logs, configure command shells and remote access programs to prevent the logging of commands that contain secret data. This practice helps in protecting secrets from unauthorized access. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Disable Command History Logging:

  • Bash: Add unset HISTFILE at the start of your session or include it in your .bashrc or .bash_profile file to prevent commands from being saved to history.
  • Zsh: Use unsetopt HIST_SAVE_NO_DUPS and set HISTSIZE=0 in your .zshrc to disable history logging.
  • Windows Command Prompt: Reduce the command history buffer size to 1.

Use Temporary Files for Secret Data:

  • Create a temporary file to store secret data
  • Restrict access to the file.
  • Write the secret to the file.
  • Immediately delete the file after use.

Clear Command History After Execution:

  • Bash: Clear history after executing sensitive commands

Configure Shell Profiles:

  • Bash: Set HISTSIZE=0 and HISTFILESIZE=0 in your .bashrc or .bash_profile to limit the size of the history file.
  • Zsh: Set HISTSIZE=0 and SAVEHIST=0 in your .zshrc to disable saving of command history.

Disable Logging in Remote Access Tools:

  • Ensure remote access programs (e.g., SSH) do not log command inputs containing sensitive information.
  • Review and adjust settings in tools like tmux and screen to avoid logging.

reference.name: Security in AWS Secrets Manager

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to AWS Secrets Manager using VPC endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that only designated network locations can access AWS Secrets Manager, use VPC endpoints to restrict access. This practice helps to isolate network traffic and enhance security by allowing only specific VPCs to communicate with AWS Secrets Manager. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Create a VPC Endpoint for Secrets Manager:

  • Open the Amazon VPC console.
  • In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints" and then "Create Endpoint."
  • Select the "AWS Services" tab and choose "com.amazonaws.<region>.secretsmanager" from the service name list.
  • Choose the VPC in which to create the endpoint.

Configure Endpoint Settings:

  • Select the route table(s) to associate with the endpoint. This will update the route tables to direct traffic destined for AWS Secrets Manager to the VPC endpoint.
  • Enable "Private DNS Name" if you want to use the standard Secrets Manager DNS names.

Set Access Policies for the VPC Endpoint:

  • Attach a policy to the VPC endpoint to control access. For example, restrict access to specific IAM users or roles.

Update Security Groups:

  • Ensure that the security groups associated with your resources allow traffic to and from the VPC endpoint. Update inbound and outbound rules as necessary.

Test the Configuration:

  • Verify that your AWS Secrets Manager operations are accessible only through the configured VPC endpoint.
  • Test from within the VPC and ensure that attempts to access Secrets Manager from outside the VPC fail.

reference.name: Control access to VPC endpoints using endpoint policies

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-22 Architecture and Provisioning for Name/address Resolution Service

countermeasure.name: Use AWS KMS for encryption key management in AWS Secrets Manager
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security and integrity of your secrets, leverage AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to manage encryption keys. AWS KMS provides a secure and centralized way to create, manage, and control cryptographic keys used to encrypt your secrets. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Enable AWS KMS for Secrets Manager:

  • By default, AWS Secrets Manager uses AWS KMS to encrypt secrets using a unique data key protected by a KMS key.
  • Ensure that AWS KMS is enabled in your AWS account and that you have the necessary permissions to use it.

Create a Customer Managed KMS Key:

  • Open the AWS KMS console.
  • Choose "Create Key" and follow the steps to define the key type, key usage, and key administrators.
  • Assign key policies to control access to the KMS key, ensuring only authorized users and roles can manage and use the key.

Configure Secrets Manager to Use the KMS Key:

  • When creating or updating a secret in AWS Secrets Manager, specify the customer-managed KMS key to be used for encryption.
  • In the Secrets Manager console, choose the "Encryption key" dropdown and select the appropriate KMS key.

reference.name: Security best practices for AWS Key Management Service

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate network access controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Inadequate Network Access Controls refer to the failure to properly restrict and secure network access to AWS Secrets Manager. This can result in unauthorized entities gaining access to sensitive secrets, leading to potential data breaches and exploitation of critical information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting weak network security configurations to access AWS Secrets Manager.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with excessive network permissions accessing secrets without proper authorization.
  • Misconfigured Network Settings: Incorrectly configured security groups, network ACLs, or VPC endpoints allowing unintended access.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive secrets.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft due to exposed secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Service outages or corrupted data.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust and business credibility.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties due to non-compliance with data protection laws.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Security Groups: Security groups are configured to allow access from any IP address, enabling attackers to connect to AWS Secrets Manager and retrieve secrets.
  2. Misconfigured VPC Endpoints: VPC endpoints are not restricted to specific subnets, allowing broader network access than intended.
  3. Insider Abuse: An employee with network access permissions abuses their access to retrieve and misuse secrets from AWS Secrets Manager.
  4. Unsecured Network ACLs: Network ACLs are not properly configured, allowing unauthorized inbound and outbound traffic to access secrets.

threat.name: Undetected anomalous activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Undetected anomalous activities refer to unusual or suspicious actions within AWS Secrets Manager that go unnoticed due to a lack of monitoring and alerting mechanisms. These activities could indicate potential security incidents, such as unauthorized access, malicious usage, or configuration changes, which, if not detected promptly, can lead to significant security breaches and data loss.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting vulnerabilities or using stolen credentials to perform unauthorized actions.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors misusing their access to perform malicious activities.
  • Automated Bots: Malicious bots performing repetitive actions that deviate from normal usage patterns.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Systems or applications unintentionally performing unexpected actions due to misconfigurations.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to and potential exfiltration of sensitive secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Unnoticed changes or deletions of secrets leading to service outages or degraded performance.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft resulting from undetected malicious activities.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust and business credibility due to delayed incident response.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to detect and report security incidents may result in legal and financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Credential Stuffing: An attacker uses a list of stolen credentials to access AWS Secrets Manager. Without monitoring, these repeated access attempts go unnoticed, leading to a breach.
  2. Insider Data Exfiltration: An employee with legitimate access slowly exfiltrates sensitive data over time. The lack of anomaly detection prevents timely discovery of the breach.
  3. Configuration Changes: An unauthorized user changes the configuration of secrets or permissions, disrupting services. Without alerts, the changes remain undetected until services are impacted.
  4. Malware Activity: Malware infects a system with access to AWS Secrets Manager and performs unauthorized activities. The lack of anomaly detection allows the malware to operate undetected for an extended period.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inter-network traffic exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Inter-Network Traffic Exposure occurs when data transmitted between AWS Secrets Manager and other systems is not adequately protected, allowing unauthorized entities to intercept, modify, or steal sensitive information. This threat arises from the use of unsecured or improperly configured network connections.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers intercepting unencrypted data transmissions over the internet or other networks.
  • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attacks: Attackers intercepting and potentially altering data between AWS Secrets Manager and its clients.
  • Improper Configuration: Misconfigured network settings or lack of encryption leading to exposure of sensitive traffic.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive secrets during transmission.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Modification of data during transmission, leading to corrupted or malicious data.
  • Operational Disruption: Interruption of services due to compromised data integrity or availability.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to exposure of sensitive data.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Violations of data protection regulations, resulting in fines and legal actions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted API Calls: An attacker intercepts unencrypted API calls between a client application and AWS Secrets Manager, gaining access to sensitive secrets.
  2. MitM Attack: An attacker positions themselves between a client and AWS Secrets Manager, capturing and possibly altering data in transit.
  3. Improper VPN Configuration: A misconfigured VPN connection exposes traffic to interception by unauthorized parties.

threat.name: Static secrets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Static secrets refer to credentials, passwords, or other sensitive data that remain unchanged over extended periods. When secrets are not rotated regularly, they become vulnerable to unauthorized access if they are leaked or discovered. Static secrets can be compromised through various means, including social engineering, brute force attacks, or insider threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers using stolen or leaked credentials to access sensitive information.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with access to static secrets misusing their access.
  • Social Engineering: Attackers tricking individuals into revealing static secrets.
  • Brute Force Attacks: Repeated attempts to guess static passwords or credentials.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information, leading to data leakage.
  • Operational Disruption: Compromised secrets can result in service outages or unauthorized changes to systems.
  • Financial Loss: Theft or fraud resulting from the misuse of static secrets.
  • Reputation Damage: Erosion of trust and credibility with customers and partners due to security breaches.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties due to failing to meet data protection standards.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Leaked Credentials: An attacker obtains static credentials from a leaked database and uses them to access AWS Secrets Manager, extracting sensitive secrets.
  2. Insider Misuse: An employee with knowledge of static secrets leaves the company but continues to use the credentials to access sensitive systems and data.
  3. Phishing Attack: An attacker successfully phishes an employee, gaining access to static secrets that have not been rotated in months.
  4. Brute Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to repeatedly attempt to guess static passwords until they gain access to sensitive accounts.

By regularly rotating secrets and implementing automated secret management practices, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with static secrets.

threat.name: Command history exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Command History Exposure happens when sensitive information, like passwords or secret keys, is saved in the command history of a shell or CLI, potentially allowing unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Threats: Employees or contractors with CLI access.
  • External Attackers: Hackers or malware exploiting access.
  • Shared Systems: Multiple users with access to the same command history.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive secrets.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft due to compromised secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Service outages or data corruption.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Shared Workstation: Another user accesses command history to find secrets.
  2. Compromised Account: Phishing attack reveals command history with secrets.
  3. Insecure Remote Access: Attacker intercepts session, accesses command history.
  4. Insider Threat: Employee uses command history to disrupt operations.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unencrypted data transmission refers to the risk associated with transmitting sensitive information, such as secrets and credentials, over a network without encryption. This lack of encryption can lead to unauthorized interception, eavesdropping, and manipulation of data during transit, compromising the confidentiality and integrity of the information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers intercepting unencrypted data packets traveling over public or internal networks.
  • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attacks: Attackers positioning themselves between the sender and receiver to capture or alter data.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with access to network traffic capturing unencrypted transmissions.
  • Network Sniffing Tools: Use of tools to monitor and capture unencrypted data packets on the network.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive secrets and credentials, leading to unauthorized access.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Alteration of data during transmission, resulting in corrupted or malicious information.
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with data transmission causing service outages or degraded performance.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft due to intercepted and misused secrets.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to compromised data security.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to comply with data protection regulations, resulting in legal and financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Intercepted API Calls: An attacker intercepts unencrypted API calls between a client application and AWS Secrets Manager, gaining access to sensitive secrets transmitted in plain text.
  2. MitM Attack on Public Network: An attacker on a public Wi-Fi network captures unencrypted data packets containing credentials and uses them to access sensitive resources.
  3. Internal Network Sniffing: An insider uses network sniffing tools to capture unencrypted secrets transmitted between internal systems, leading to unauthorized access.
  4. Compromised VPN Connection: A VPN connection without proper encryption is compromised, allowing an attacker to intercept sensitive data transmitted between on-premises networks and AWS Secrets Manager.

threat.name: Improper encryption key management
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Improper Encryption Key Management involves weaknesses in the creation, storage, distribution, rotation, and destruction of encryption keys used to protect secrets in AWS Secrets Manager. Inadequate management of encryption keys can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and compromised data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Threats: Employees or contractors mishandling encryption keys.
  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting weak key management practices.
  • Insider Threats: Malicious insiders misusing encryption keys.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Improperly configured key policies or permissions.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to encrypted secrets.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Corrupted or tampered data.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft due to exposed secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Service outages and loss of data availability.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties due to non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Weak Key Policies: An attacker exploits a weakly configured key policy to decrypt secrets.
  2. Unrotated Keys: Stale encryption keys are compromised, giving an attacker access to encrypted data.
  3. Excessive Permissions: An insider with unnecessary permissions accesses and misuses encryption keys.
  4. Misconfigured KMS: Misconfiguration in AWS KMS allows unauthorized users to generate or access keys.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Untracked user activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Untracked user activities refer to the lack of monitoring and logging of actions performed by users within AWS Secrets Manager. This absence of tracking can lead to undetected unauthorized access, changes, or misuse of secrets, compromising the security and integrity of the system. Without detailed logs, it is challenging to perform audits, identify security incidents, and attribute actions to specific users.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers gaining unauthorized access and performing actions without detection.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors misusing their access without being tracked.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Systems lacking proper logging configurations, leading to unmonitored activities.
  • Automated Scripts: Scripts or bots performing actions that are not logged or monitored.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to and potential exfiltration of sensitive secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Unmonitored changes leading to service disruptions or data integrity issues.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft resulting from undetected malicious activities.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to undetected and unaddressed security incidents.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to comply with data protection regulations requiring activity logging, resulting in legal and financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to AWS Secrets Manager and retrieves sensitive secrets without being detected due to lack of logging.
  2. Insider Misuse: An employee with legitimate access modifies or deletes secrets, and the actions go untracked, preventing timely detection and response.
  3. Configuration Changes: Unauthorized configuration changes made by users are not logged, leading to potential security weaknesses that remain unnoticed.
  4. Malware Activity: Malware infects a system and performs unauthorized actions within AWS Secrets Manager, which are not tracked due to missing logs.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Configure CloudWatch alarms for unusual activity in AWS Secrets Manager
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS Secrets Manager, set up AWS CloudWatch alarms to monitor and alert on any unusual activity or access patterns. This involves configuring CloudWatch metrics and creating alarms for specific actions that could indicate potential security incidents. Follow these steps to implement this control:

  1. Enable CloudTrail Logging: Ensure AWS CloudTrail is enabled to log all API calls to AWS Secrets Manager.
  2. Define Key Metrics: Identify critical metrics to monitor, such as:
    • GetSecretValue
    • PutSecretValue
    • DeleteSecret
  3. Set Thresholds: Establish thresholds for these metrics that would indicate abnormal activity, such as a high frequency of secret retrievals or deletions.
  4. Create Alarms: In AWS CloudWatch, create alarms for these metrics. Configure them to trigger notifications if thresholds are exceeded.
  5. Configure Notifications: Set up AWS SNS (Simple Notification Service) to send alerts to designated personnel or systems in real-time.
  6. Regular Review: Periodically review and update the metrics, thresholds, and alarm configurations to ensure they remain effective and relevant.

reference.name: Security in AWS Secrets Manager
