countermeasure.name: Enable automatic secret rotation in AWS Secrets Manager
countermeasure.desc:
To minimize the risk of unauthorized access due to stale or compromised secrets, configure AWS Secrets Manager to automatically rotate secrets at regular intervals. This ensures that secrets are periodically updated, reducing the likelihood of them being exploited by malicious actors. Follow these steps to implement automatic secret rotation:

Enable Secret Rotation:

  • Go to the AWS Secrets Manager console.
  • Select the secret you want to enable rotation for.
  • Click on "Rotate secret".

Define Rotation Schedule:

  • Choose a predefined schedule or specify a custom rotation interval (e.g., every 30 days). Use cron expressions for more granular control if needed.

Create a Lambda Function:

  • Develop an AWS Lambda function that handles the rotation logic. This function should:
    • Retrieve the current secret.
    • Generate a new version of the secret.
    • Update the secret in the relevant service or application.
    • Test the new secret to ensure it works correctly.
  • AWS provides sample Lambda functions for different use cases that can be customized to fit your requirements.

Attach the Lambda Function to the Secret:

  • In the rotation configuration, specify the ARN of the Lambda function that you created.
  • Configure the Lambda execution role with appropriate permissions to read and update the secret, as well as to update the application using the secret.

Test the Rotation Configuration:

  • Manually trigger a rotation to ensure that the Lambda function executes correctly and the secret updates without issues.
  • Monitor the logs and verify that the new secret is functioning as expected in the application.

reference.name: Rotate AWS Secrets Manager secrets

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2 or higher for AWS Secrets Manager communications
countermeasure.desc:
To protect data in transit and ensure the security of sensitive information, configure AWS Secrets Manager to use TLS 1.2 or higher for all communications. This ensures that data exchanged between AWS Secrets Manager and its clients is encrypted and secure from interception or tampering by unauthorized entities. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Verify TLS Configuration:

  • Ensure that all endpoints communicating with AWS Secrets Manager are configured to use TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • AWS Secrets Manager supports TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3 by default for all API operations.

Update Client Applications:

  • Ensure that all client applications interacting with AWS Secrets Manager are updated to support TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • Update libraries and SDKs used by your applications to their latest versions, as they often include improved security features and support for modern TLS protocols.

Enforce TLS in Application Code:

  • Modify your application code to explicitly require TLS 1.2 or higher for connections to AWS Secrets Manager.
  • For example, in Python, use the botocore library which supports TLS 1.2 by default
  • In Java, ensure that the JVM is configured to use TLS 1.2 or higher:

Configure Network Settings:

  • Use security groups and network ACLs to restrict traffic to only those endpoints that support TLS 1.2 or higher.
  • Ensure that load balancers, proxies, and other network devices are configured to enforce TLS 1.2 or higher for inbound and outbound traffic.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config to monitor API calls and verify that all communications with AWS Secrets Manager are using the appropriate TLS version.
  • Set up CloudWatch Alarms to detect and alert on any communications that do not comply with the TLS 1.2 or higher requirement.

reference.name: Security in AWS Secrets Manager

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Log all API calls to AWS Secrets Manager with AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
To enable comprehensive tracking and auditing of all user activities in AWS Secrets Manager, set up AWS CloudTrail to log all API calls. This helps in monitoring access patterns, detecting unauthorized actions, and maintaining an audit trail for compliance purposes. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Enable CloudTrail in Your AWS Account: Ensure that AWS CloudTrail is enabled in the AWS region where your AWS Secrets Manager is deployed.

  • Go to the AWS CloudTrail console.
  • If you do not have a trail, create a new one by clicking "Create trail."
  • Configure the trail to apply to all regions for comprehensive coverage.

Configure Logging for All API Calls: Ensure that the CloudTrail configuration includes logging for all API calls to AWS Secrets Manager.

  • In the trail settings, enable management and data events logging.
  • Include the AWS Secrets Manager service in the data events to capture all API interactions.

Store Logs in a Secure S3 Bucket: Designate an Amazon S3 bucket to store CloudTrail logs securely.

  • Ensure the S3 bucket has appropriate access policies to prevent unauthorized access.
  • Enable server-side encryption for log files stored in the S3 bucket.

Set Up Log Validation and Integrity Checks: Enable log file validation in CloudTrail to ensure the integrity of the log files.

  • This helps in detecting any tampering of log data.

Monitor and Analyze Logs: Use AWS CloudWatch Logs to monitor and analyze the logs generated by CloudTrail.

  • Set up CloudWatch log groups and streams to collect and store CloudTrail logs.
  • Create metrics and alarms to detect unusual activities or patterns indicating potential security issues.

reference.name: What Is AWS CloudTrail?

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

countermeasure.name: Maintain privacy and security of traffic to AWS Secrets Manager using private network routes
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the privacy and security of traffic to AWS Secrets Manager, use private network routes such as AWS PrivateLink, VPN, or AWS Direct Connect. These methods help isolate traffic from the public internet, reducing the risk of interception and unauthorized access. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Set Up AWS PrivateLink:

  • Create an Interface VPC Endpoint:
    • Open the Amazon VPC console.
    • In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints" and then "Create Endpoint."
    • Select "AWS Services" and choose "com.amazonaws.<region>.secretsmanager" from the service name list.
    • Select the VPC in which to create the endpoint.
    • Choose the subnets and security groups that will allow access to the endpoint.
  • Configure DNS:
    • Ensure that "Enable DNS name" is selected to allow private DNS resolution within your VPC.
  • Update Security Groups:
    • Modify the security groups associated with your resources to allow traffic from the VPC endpoint.

Set Up AWS Site-to-Site VPN:

  • Create a VPN Connection:
    • Open the Amazon VPC console.
    • In the navigation pane, choose "VPN Connections" and then "Create VPN Connection."
    • Configure the customer gateway and virtual private gateway settings.
    • Once the VPN connection is created, configure your on-premises router with the provided configuration details.
  • Establish the VPN Tunnel:
    • Ensure the VPN tunnels are up and that traffic is routing through the VPN connection.
  • Update Routing Tables:
    • Update the route tables in your VPC to direct traffic destined for AWS Secrets Manager through the VPN connection.

Set Up AWS Direct Connect:

  • Create a Direct Connect Connection:
    • Open the AWS Direct Connect console.
    • Choose "Create Connection" and select the appropriate location and port speed.
    • Once the connection is provisioned, set up the Direct Connect gateway and virtual interfaces (VIFs) to connect to your VPC.
  • Configure Network Routing:
    • Update your network routing to ensure that traffic to AWS Secrets Manager uses the Direct Connect path.

Configure Security Groups and Network ACLs:

  • Ensure that security groups and network ACLs are configured to allow traffic only from your private network routes (VPC endpoints, VPN connections, or Direct Connect).
  • Implement least privilege principles to restrict access only to necessary resources.

reference.name: What is Amazon VPC?

countermeasure.name: Prevent logging of sensitive commands in command shells
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard sensitive information from being inadvertently stored in command history logs, configure command shells and remote access programs to prevent the logging of commands that contain secret data. This practice helps in protecting secrets from unauthorized access. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Disable Command History Logging:

  • Bash: Add unset HISTFILE at the start of your session or include it in your .bashrc or .bash_profile file to prevent commands from being saved to history.
  • Zsh: Use unsetopt HIST_SAVE_NO_DUPS and set HISTSIZE=0 in your .zshrc to disable history logging.
  • Windows Command Prompt: Reduce the command history buffer size to 1.

Use Temporary Files for Secret Data:

  • Create a temporary file to store secret data
  • Restrict access to the file.
  • Write the secret to the file.
  • Immediately delete the file after use.

Clear Command History After Execution:

  • Bash: Clear history after executing sensitive commands

Configure Shell Profiles:

  • Bash: Set HISTSIZE=0 and HISTFILESIZE=0 in your .bashrc or .bash_profile to limit the size of the history file.
  • Zsh: Set HISTSIZE=0 and SAVEHIST=0 in your .zshrc to disable saving of command history.

Disable Logging in Remote Access Tools:

  • Ensure remote access programs (e.g., SSH) do not log command inputs containing sensitive information.
  • Review and adjust settings in tools like tmux and screen to avoid logging.

reference.name: Security in AWS Secrets Manager

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to AWS Secrets Manager using VPC endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that only designated network locations can access AWS Secrets Manager, use VPC endpoints to restrict access. This practice helps to isolate network traffic and enhance security by allowing only specific VPCs to communicate with AWS Secrets Manager. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Create a VPC Endpoint for Secrets Manager:

  • Open the Amazon VPC console.
  • In the navigation pane, choose "Endpoints" and then "Create Endpoint."
  • Select the "AWS Services" tab and choose "com.amazonaws.<region>.secretsmanager" from the service name list.
  • Choose the VPC in which to create the endpoint.

Configure Endpoint Settings:

  • Select the route table(s) to associate with the endpoint. This will update the route tables to direct traffic destined for AWS Secrets Manager to the VPC endpoint.
  • Enable "Private DNS Name" if you want to use the standard Secrets Manager DNS names.

Set Access Policies for the VPC Endpoint:

  • Attach a policy to the VPC endpoint to control access. For example, restrict access to specific IAM users or roles.

Update Security Groups:

  • Ensure that the security groups associated with your resources allow traffic to and from the VPC endpoint. Update inbound and outbound rules as necessary.

Test the Configuration:

  • Verify that your AWS Secrets Manager operations are accessible only through the configured VPC endpoint.
  • Test from within the VPC and ensure that attempts to access Secrets Manager from outside the VPC fail.

reference.name: Control access to VPC endpoints using endpoint policies

PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Use AWS KMS for encryption key management in AWS Secrets Manager
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security and integrity of your secrets, leverage AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to manage encryption keys. AWS KMS provides a secure and centralized way to create, manage, and control cryptographic keys used to encrypt your secrets. Follow these steps to implement this control:

Enable AWS KMS for Secrets Manager:

  • By default, AWS Secrets Manager uses AWS KMS to encrypt secrets using a unique data key protected by a KMS key.
  • Ensure that AWS KMS is enabled in your AWS account and that you have the necessary permissions to use it.

Create a Customer Managed KMS Key:

  • Open the AWS KMS console.
  • Choose "Create Key" and follow the steps to define the key type, key usage, and key administrators.
  • Assign key policies to control access to the KMS key, ensuring only authorized users and roles can manage and use the key.

Configure Secrets Manager to Use the KMS Key:

  • When creating or updating a secret in AWS Secrets Manager, specify the customer-managed KMS key to be used for encryption.
  • In the Secrets Manager console, choose the "Encryption key" dropdown and select the appropriate KMS key.

reference.name: Security best practices for AWS Key Management Service

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate network access controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Inadequate Network Access Controls refer to the failure to properly restrict and secure network access to AWS Secrets Manager. This can result in unauthorized entities gaining access to sensitive secrets, leading to potential data breaches and exploitation of critical information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting weak network security configurations to access AWS Secrets Manager.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with excessive network permissions accessing secrets without proper authorization.
  • Misconfigured Network Settings: Incorrectly configured security groups, network ACLs, or VPC endpoints allowing unintended access.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive secrets.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft due to exposed secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Service outages or corrupted data.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust and business credibility.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties due to non-compliance with data protection laws.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Security Groups: Security groups are configured to allow access from any IP address, enabling attackers to connect to AWS Secrets Manager and retrieve secrets.
  2. Misconfigured VPC Endpoints: VPC endpoints are not restricted to specific subnets, allowing broader network access than intended.
  3. Insider Abuse: An employee with network access permissions abuses their access to retrieve and misuse secrets from AWS Secrets Manager.
  4. Unsecured Network ACLs: Network ACLs are not properly configured, allowing unauthorized inbound and outbound traffic to access secrets.

threat.name: Undetected anomalous activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Undetected anomalous activities refer to unusual or suspicious actions within AWS Secrets Manager that go unnoticed due to a lack of monitoring and alerting mechanisms. These activities could indicate potential security incidents, such as unauthorized access, malicious usage, or configuration changes, which, if not detected promptly, can lead to significant security breaches and data loss.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting vulnerabilities or using stolen credentials to perform unauthorized actions.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors misusing their access to perform malicious activities.
  • Automated Bots: Malicious bots performing repetitive actions that deviate from normal usage patterns.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Systems or applications unintentionally performing unexpected actions due to misconfigurations.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to and potential exfiltration of sensitive secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Unnoticed changes or deletions of secrets leading to service outages or degraded performance.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft resulting from undetected malicious activities.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust and business credibility due to delayed incident response.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to detect and report security incidents may result in legal and financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Credential Stuffing: An attacker uses a list of stolen credentials to access AWS Secrets Manager. Without monitoring, these repeated access attempts go unnoticed, leading to a breach.
  2. Insider Data Exfiltration: An employee with legitimate access slowly exfiltrates sensitive data over time. The lack of anomaly detection prevents timely discovery of the breach.
  3. Configuration Changes: An unauthorized user changes the configuration of secrets or permissions, disrupting services. Without alerts, the changes remain undetected until services are impacted.
  4. Malware Activity: Malware infects a system with access to AWS Secrets Manager and performs unauthorized activities. The lack of anomaly detection allows the malware to operate undetected for an extended period.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inter-network traffic exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Inter-Network Traffic Exposure occurs when data transmitted between AWS Secrets Manager and other systems is not adequately protected, allowing unauthorized entities to intercept, modify, or steal sensitive information. This threat arises from the use of unsecured or improperly configured network connections.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers intercepting unencrypted data transmissions over the internet or other networks.
  • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attacks: Attackers intercepting and potentially altering data between AWS Secrets Manager and its clients.
  • Improper Configuration: Misconfigured network settings or lack of encryption leading to exposure of sensitive traffic.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive secrets during transmission.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Modification of data during transmission, leading to corrupted or malicious data.
  • Operational Disruption: Interruption of services due to compromised data integrity or availability.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to exposure of sensitive data.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Violations of data protection regulations, resulting in fines and legal actions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted API Calls: An attacker intercepts unencrypted API calls between a client application and AWS Secrets Manager, gaining access to sensitive secrets.
  2. MitM Attack: An attacker positions themselves between a client and AWS Secrets Manager, capturing and possibly altering data in transit.
  3. Improper VPN Configuration: A misconfigured VPN connection exposes traffic to interception by unauthorized parties.

threat.name: Command history exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Command History Exposure happens when sensitive information, like passwords or secret keys, is saved in the command history of a shell or CLI, potentially allowing unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Threats: Employees or contractors with CLI access.
  • External Attackers: Hackers or malware exploiting access.
  • Shared Systems: Multiple users with access to the same command history.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive secrets.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft due to compromised secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Service outages or data corruption.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Shared Workstation: Another user accesses command history to find secrets.
  2. Compromised Account: Phishing attack reveals command history with secrets.
  3. Insecure Remote Access: Attacker intercepts session, accesses command history.
  4. Insider Threat: Employee uses command history to disrupt operations.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unencrypted data transmission refers to the risk associated with transmitting sensitive information, such as secrets and credentials, over a network without encryption. This lack of encryption can lead to unauthorized interception, eavesdropping, and manipulation of data during transit, compromising the confidentiality and integrity of the information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers intercepting unencrypted data packets traveling over public or internal networks.
  • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attacks: Attackers positioning themselves between the sender and receiver to capture or alter data.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with access to network traffic capturing unencrypted transmissions.
  • Network Sniffing Tools: Use of tools to monitor and capture unencrypted data packets on the network.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive secrets and credentials, leading to unauthorized access.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Alteration of data during transmission, resulting in corrupted or malicious information.
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with data transmission causing service outages or degraded performance.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft due to intercepted and misused secrets.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to compromised data security.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to comply with data protection regulations, resulting in legal and financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Intercepted API Calls: An attacker intercepts unencrypted API calls between a client application and AWS Secrets Manager, gaining access to sensitive secrets transmitted in plain text.
  2. MitM Attack on Public Network: An attacker on a public Wi-Fi network captures unencrypted data packets containing credentials and uses them to access sensitive resources.
  3. Internal Network Sniffing: An insider uses network sniffing tools to capture unencrypted secrets transmitted between internal systems, leading to unauthorized access.
  4. Compromised VPN Connection: A VPN connection without proper encryption is compromised, allowing an attacker to intercept sensitive data transmitted between on-premises networks and AWS Secrets Manager.

threat.name: Improper encryption key management
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Improper Encryption Key Management involves weaknesses in the creation, storage, distribution, rotation, and destruction of encryption keys used to protect secrets in AWS Secrets Manager. Inadequate management of encryption keys can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and compromised data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Threats: Employees or contractors mishandling encryption keys.
  • External Attackers: Hackers exploiting weak key management practices.
  • Insider Threats: Malicious insiders misusing encryption keys.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Improperly configured key policies or permissions.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to encrypted secrets.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Corrupted or tampered data.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft due to exposed secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Service outages and loss of data availability.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties due to non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Weak Key Policies: An attacker exploits a weakly configured key policy to decrypt secrets.
  2. Unrotated Keys: Stale encryption keys are compromised, giving an attacker access to encrypted data.
  3. Excessive Permissions: An insider with unnecessary permissions accesses and misuses encryption keys.
  4. Misconfigured KMS: Misconfiguration in AWS KMS allows unauthorized users to generate or access keys.

threat.name: Static secrets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Static secrets refer to credentials, passwords, or other sensitive data that remain unchanged over extended periods. When secrets are not rotated regularly, they become vulnerable to unauthorized access if they are leaked or discovered. Static secrets can be compromised through various means, including social engineering, brute force attacks, or insider threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers using stolen or leaked credentials to access sensitive information.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors with access to static secrets misusing their access.
  • Social Engineering: Attackers tricking individuals into revealing static secrets.
  • Brute Force Attacks: Repeated attempts to guess static passwords or credentials.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive information, leading to data leakage.
  • Operational Disruption: Compromised secrets can result in service outages or unauthorized changes to systems.
  • Financial Loss: Theft or fraud resulting from the misuse of static secrets.
  • Reputation Damage: Erosion of trust and credibility with customers and partners due to security breaches.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Legal and financial penalties due to failing to meet data protection standards.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Leaked Credentials: An attacker obtains static credentials from a leaked database and uses them to access AWS Secrets Manager, extracting sensitive secrets.
  2. Insider Misuse: An employee with knowledge of static secrets leaves the company but continues to use the credentials to access sensitive systems and data.
  3. Phishing Attack: An attacker successfully phishes an employee, gaining access to static secrets that have not been rotated in months.
  4. Brute Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to repeatedly attempt to guess static passwords until they gain access to sensitive accounts.

By regularly rotating secrets and implementing automated secret management practices, organizations can significantly reduce the risk associated with static secrets.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Untracked user activities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Untracked user activities refer to the lack of monitoring and logging of actions performed by users within AWS Secrets Manager. This absence of tracking can lead to undetected unauthorized access, changes, or misuse of secrets, compromising the security and integrity of the system. Without detailed logs, it is challenging to perform audits, identify security incidents, and attribute actions to specific users.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Hackers gaining unauthorized access and performing actions without detection.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors misusing their access without being tracked.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Systems lacking proper logging configurations, leading to unmonitored activities.
  • Automated Scripts: Scripts or bots performing actions that are not logged or monitored.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to and potential exfiltration of sensitive secrets.
  • Operational Disruption: Unmonitored changes leading to service disruptions or data integrity issues.
  • Financial Loss: Fraud or theft resulting from undetected malicious activities.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to undetected and unaddressed security incidents.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Failure to comply with data protection regulations requiring activity logging, resulting in legal and financial penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to AWS Secrets Manager and retrieves sensitive secrets without being detected due to lack of logging.
  2. Insider Misuse: An employee with legitimate access modifies or deletes secrets, and the actions go untracked, preventing timely detection and response.
  3. Configuration Changes: Unauthorized configuration changes made by users are not logged, leading to potential security weaknesses that remain unnoticed.
  4. Malware Activity: Malware infects a system and performs unauthorized actions within AWS Secrets Manager, which are not tracked due to missing logs.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Block public sharing for SSM documents
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of AWS Systems Manager (SSM) and ensure that sensitive documents are not shared publicly, it is essential to disable public sharing of SSM documents in the Preferences section. This can be achieved by performing the following steps:

  1. Open the AWS Systems Manager console.

  2. In the navigation pane, choose Documents.

  3. Select the Preferences tab.

  4. Locate the setting for public document sharing. Ensure that public sharing of documents is disabled by setting the preference to No or Only with IAM roles and users in your account.

  5. Save your preferences to apply the changes.

By implementing this precaution, you ensure that only authorized users within your AWS account can access sensitive SSM documents, thereby mitigating the risk of accidental or unauthorized public access. For detailed guidance on securing SSM documents, refer to the official AWS Systems Manager Security Best Practices.

countermeasure.name: Define allowedValues and allowedPattern for parameters
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS Systems Manager (SSM) documents and prevent invalid inputs, it's crucial to enforce validation of user inputs using the allowedValues and allowedPattern settings. This practice helps to ensure that the input parameters conform to expected formats and predefined values, thereby mitigating the risk of passing erroneous or malicious data to your SSM documents.

To implement this security control, follow these steps:

  1. Edit your SSM document and identify the parameters that require validation.
  2. Use the allowedValues attribute to specify a list of acceptable values for parameters. For example:
{
  "Parameters": {
    "InstanceType": {
      "Type": "String",
      "Description": "The instance type to use",
      "AllowedValues": ["t2.micro", "t2.small", "t2.medium"]
    }
  }
}
  1. Alternatively, use the allowedPattern attribute to define a regular expression that the parameter values must match. For example:
{
  "Parameters": {
    "KeyName": {
      "Type": "String",
      "Description": "The name of the key pair",
      "AllowedPattern": "^[a-zA-Z0-9._-]{3,255}$"
    }
  }
}
  1. Save your SSM document changes and test to ensure that only valid inputs are accepted based on the defined allowedValues and allowedPattern settings.

By adhering to these guidelines, you can significantly reduce the likelihood of introducing invalid or potentially harmful inputs into your system. For more detailed security best practices, refer to the official AWS Systems Manager Security Best Practices documentation.

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Use SecureString parameters with customer managed keys
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of sensitive data stored in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store, it is crucial to utilize SecureString parameters in conjunction with customer-managed AWS KMS keys. This allows for precise control over who can access sensitive information.

Follow the steps below to implement this control:

  1. Create a Customer Managed Key (CMK) in AWS KMS:
    • Navigate to the AWS KMS console.
    • Select Create Key and follow the wizard to define key settings, such as an alias, description, and key usage permissions.
  2. Define IAM Policies for Access Control:
    • Create IAM policies that grant necessary permissions to access the CMK. Ensure you follow the principle of least privilege.
    • Attach these policies to the IAM roles or users who need access to the SecureString parameters.
  3. Create SecureString Parameters:
    • Open the AWS Systems Manager console and navigate to Parameter Store.
    • Choose Create Parameter.
    • Specify the parameter type as SecureString.
    • Under the KMS Key Source section, select Customer Managed Key and choose the CMK you created.
    • Provide the necessary parameter values and metadata, then save the parameter.
  4. Access and Use SecureString Parameters Safely:
    • Ensure that applications or services accessing these parameters have the requisite IAM permissions to decrypt the CMK.
    • Reference SecureString parameters securely in your application code using AWS SDKs or AWS CLI.

By following these steps, you can ensure that sensitive data is encrypted and access-controlled using customer-managed AWS KMS keys, thereby enhancing the security posture of your AWS environment.

For additional information, please refer to the AWS Systems Manager Security Best Practices documentation.

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Publicly accessible SSM documents
threat.desc:
General threat description
Publicly shared SSM documents can be misused, leading to security risks or unauthorized actions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers or unauthorized users who gain access to publicly shared SSM documents can exploit them. This can be facilitated through accidentally or intentionally sharing SSM documents with public or wide-reaching permissions.
Impacts
This misuse can lead to unauthorized actions being executed within AWS environments, potential data breaches, system disruptions, or exploitation of AWS resources for malicious activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers a publicly shared SSM document containing automation scripts and utilizes this information to perform unauthorized actions, such as shutting down servers, exfiltrating data, or gaining further access within the AWS environment.

threat.name: Unsecured sensitive data in Parameter Store
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data stored in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store can be exposed if not properly encrypted.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or attackers who gain unauthorized access could exploit improperly encrypted data.
Impacts
Exposure of sensitive data leading to data breaches, financial losses, legal repercussions, and damage to reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store and extracts configuration information, including API keys and passwords, due to encryption not being properly enforced.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Improper validation of user input in SSM documents
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of proper validation for user input in SSM documents may allow invalid or malicious inputs to be used, potentially leading to failures or vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include external attackers, malicious insiders, or even unintentional mistakes by legitimate users. Attack vectors may involve submitting specially crafted inputs that exploit the lack of validation.
Impacts
The impacts can include execution of arbitrary commands, privilege escalation, data breaches, and disruption of services.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker inputs malicious commands into an SSM document, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data or infrastructure disruption. Another scenario involves a user unintentionally entering incorrect data, causing system failures or unexpected behavior.

weakness.name: CWE-347
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-347: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature The product does not verify, or incorrectly verifies, the cryptographic signature for data.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Enforce a model of least privilege for source code repositories
countermeasure.desc:
Least privilege is the principle that a security architecture should be designed so that each entity is granted the minimum system resources and authorizations that the entity needs to perform its function.

Remediation:
Consider the exposure of your repository. Technically enforce a model of least privilege for who can make changes to your code repository. Make sure all activity is attributable.

Additionally, access to the repository should be revoked swiftly when no longer required, or in the event of compromise

Reference:

  • Protect access credentials

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1024 - Restrict Registry Permissions

countermeasure.name: Layer a process of cryptographic signing for source code repositories
countermeasure.desc:
Code signing uses cryptographic hashing that can validate the authenticity of software and ensure the integrity of code by verifying it has not been tampered with since being published. Code signing plays an important role in verifying the integrity of software used or distributed by organizations and individuals.

Remediation:
Layer a process of cryptographic signing and verifying code on top of the repository which can help to increase confidence that the code has not been tampered with.

Reference:

  • Protect access credentials

SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Protect access credentials in source code repositories
countermeasure.desc:
User access to repositories is often authenticated using credentials, such as passwords or private keys. Loss of these credentials may allow an attacker to gain unauthorized access.

Remediation:
Ensure that developers are encouraged to protect these credentials while they are used and managed within your development environment. 
Private keys should be password protected. Backing them onto a hardware token that makes them harder to abuse. 
Consider the option of rotating access keys.

Reference:

  • Protect access credentials

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Excessive access permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Granting excessive access permissions within a source code repository can expose sensitive code to unauthorized modifications, leaks, or potential misuse. Without enforcing least privilege access, users may inadvertently or intentionally make changes or access parts of the repository beyond their operational needs, increasing security risks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents internal users with excessive permissions, compromised user accounts, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors unrestrained access rights, lack of role-based access control, absence of periodic access reviews

Impacts

  • Data Breach unauthorized access may lead to the exposure of proprietary or sensitive code
  • Code Tampering excessive privileges enable unauthorized modifications, risking software integrity
  • Operational Disruption improper access can lead to unintentional or malicious disruptions in development workflows

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unauthorized Code Access a developer with broad access permissions views sensitive portions of the codebase, leading to a potential data leak.
  2. Code Manipulation a malicious insider uses admin privileges to inject unapproved code, introducing vulnerabilities or backdoors.
  3. Unintentional Data Exposure a user with unnecessary access privileges accidentally shares sensitive code files externally, leading to a data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1214 - Credentials in Registry

threat.name: Exposure of access credentials
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Storing access credentials, such as API keys or passwords, directly within a source code repository can lead to unauthorized access if those credentials are leaked or discovered. Exposed credentials can allow attackers to compromise other systems, services, or sensitive resources linked to the codebase.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents external attackers, malicious insiders, automated scanning bots
  • Attack Vectors hard-coded credentials in code, unencrypted credentials files, inadvertent exposure through public repositories

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access attackers can use exposed credentials to gain access to sensitive systems or services
  • Data Breach access to connected systems may expose sensitive data or confidential resources
  • Service Disruption unauthorized use of credentials can lead to misuse, service interruptions, or resource exhaustion

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Repository Exposure credentials accidentally committed to a public repository are discovered by attackers, who use them to access a sensitive internal service.
  2. Credential Harvesting automated bots scan repositories for unencrypted keys, finding exposed credentials that grant access to cloud resources.
  3. Malicious Insider an insider retrieves credentials from code and uses them to access restricted resources or manipulate data.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Tampering with source code
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized modifications to source code within a repository can introduce vulnerabilities, malware, or unauthorized changes, compromising the integrity and security of the software. Tampering with code can lead to security breaches, unexpected behavior, or the deployment of malicious functionality in production environments.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents malicious insiders, compromised user accounts, external attackers
  • Attack Vectors unauthorized access to repositories, lack of code review processes, insufficient access controls

Impacts

  • Software Integrity Compromise modified code can introduce vulnerabilities or malware, affecting the reliability and security of the software
  • Operational Risks tampered code can lead to unexpected software behavior, service disruptions, or performance issues
  • Reputational Damage if malicious changes are deployed, it could lead to trust issues and impact the organization's reputation

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Backdoor Insertion a malicious insider with access injects a backdoor into the source code, allowing unauthorized future access.
  2. Vulnerability Introduction an attacker who gains unauthorized access modifies code to introduce a vulnerability, compromising the applications security.
  3. Undetected Malware Injection a compromised account injects malware into the codebase, which goes unnoticed due to lack of code signing or validation.

Implementing cryptographic signing for code commits, enforcing code reviews, and restricting write access can help prevent source code tampering and maintain code integrity.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578 - Modify Cloud Compute Infrastructure

weakness.name: CWE-1047
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1047: Modules with Circular Dependencies The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

weakness.name: CWE-1193
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1193: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-300
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-300: Channel Accessible by Non-Endpoint The product does not adequately verify the identity of actors at both ends of a communication channel, or does not adequately ensure the integrity of the channel, in a way that allows the channel to be accessed or influenced by an actor that is not an endpoint. In order to establish secure communication between two parties, it is often important to adequately verify the identity of entities at each end of the communication channel. Inadequate or inconsistent verification may result in insufficient or incorrect identification of either communicating entity. This can have negative consequences such as misplaced trust in the entity at the other end of the channel. An attacker can leverage this by interposing between the communicating entities and masquerading as the original entity. In the absence of sufficient verification of identity, such an attacker can eavesdrop and potentially modify the communication between the original entities.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-312
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-312: Cleartext Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information in cleartext within a resource that might be accessible to another control sphere.

weakness.name: CWE-353
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-353: Missing Support for Integrity Check The product uses a transmission protocol that does not include a mechanism for verifying the integrity of the data during transmission, such as a checksum. If integrity check values or "checksums" are omitted from a protocol, there is no way of determining if data has been corrupted in transmission. The lack of checksum functionality in a protocol removes the first application-level check of data that can be used. The end-to-end philosophy of checks states that integrity checks should be performed at the lowest level that they can be completely implemented. Excluding further sanity checks and input validation performed by applications, the protocol's checksum is the most important level of checksum, since it can be performed more completely than at any previous level and takes into account entire messages, as opposed to single packets.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-416
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-416: Use After Free Referencing memory after it has been freed can cause a program to crash, use unexpected values, or execute code.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-540
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-540: Inclusion of Sensitive Information in Source Code Source code on a web server or repository often contains sensitive information and should generally not be accessible to users. There are situations where it is critical to remove source code from an area or server. For example, obtaining Perl source code on a system allows an attacker to understand the logic of the script and extract extremely useful information such as code bugs or logins and passwords.

weakness.name: CWE-672
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-672: Operation on a Resource after Expiration or Release The product uses, accesses, or otherwise operates on a resource after that resource has been expired, released, or revoked.

weakness.name: CWE-913
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-913: Improper Control of Dynamically-Managed Code Resources The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-managed code resources such as variables, objects, classes, attributes, functions, or executable instructions or statements. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to dynamically create or modify existing code, or resources used by code such as variables and objects. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can directly influence these code resources in unexpected ways.

countermeasure.name: Apply permission boundaries to cap Lambda role and user privileges
countermeasure.desc:
Define a single IAM permission-boundary policy that represents the maximum set of actions a Lambda workload should ever performtypically the core lambda:*, CloudWatch Logs calls, and tightly scoped access to specific AWS resources. Attach that boundary to:

  • Every Lambda execution role (via the PermissionBoundary property in CloudFormation/Terraform).
  • All human or CI/CD principals that can create or update functions.

Because AWS evaluates the boundary before attached or inline policies, anything not explicitly allowed by the boundary is automatically deniedeven if someone tries to grant broader rights later.

quick implementation

  1. Author and publish the boundary
    1. {
       "Version":"2012-10-17",
       "Statement":[
         { "Effect":"Allow", "Action":[
             "lambda:*",
             "logs:CreateLogGroup", "logs:CreateLogStream", "logs:PutLogEvents"
           ], "Resource":"*" },
         { "Effect":"Deny", "Action":[ "iam:*", "organizations:*", "lambda:DeleteFunction" ], "Resource":"*" }
       ]
      }
       
    2. aws iam create-policy --policy-name lambda-boundary --policy-document file://boundary.json
  2. Attach the boundary
    1. aws iam put-role-permissions-boundary \
          --role-name OrderProcessorRole \
          --permissions-boundary arn:aws:iam::<acct>:policy/lambda-boundary
  3. Enforce automatically
    • Add a pipeline check (e.g., cfn-lint, Checkov) that fails if a new role lacks PermissionBoundary.
    • Enable AWS Config rule iam-user-permissions-boundary-check and create a similar custom rule for roles to detect drift.
  4. Maintain
    Review the boundary every quarter: remove unused Allow actions, add new ones only after peer approval, and keep the policy version history in source control.

References

  • Permissions boundaries for IAM entities
  • Lambda security best practices IAM boundaries

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Deploy VPC Lambda functions across multiple Availability Zones
countermeasure.desc:
For every Lambda function that runs inside a VPC, attach at least two private subnets that reside in different Availability Zones (AZs). Lambda automatically spreads function instances across all subnets you specify, so providing subnets in multiple AZs gives the function resiliency against an AZ-level failure.

Implementation steps

  1. Subnet planning In the target VPC, create two or more /24 (or smaller) private subnets, each located in a distinct AZ (for example, subnet-az1a-private, subnet-az1b-private). If the function needs outbound internet access, give every AZ its own NAT gateway or egress path.
  2. Configure the function
    • Console: Configuration VPC Edit select the VPC and tick both (or all) private subnets.
    • AWS CLI / IaC:
      • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
         --function-name order-processor \
         --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0a12,subnet-0b34,SecurityGroupIds=sg-0abc
  3. Security groups Attach a least-privilege security group that allows only the ports and CIDRs the function truly needs (for example, TCP 5432 to an RDS cluster SG).
  4. Guardrails Implement an AWS Config custom rule or cfn-nag check that fails a deployment when a VPC-connected Lambda lists fewer than two subnets.
  5. Validation & monitoring Use the Lambda consoles Monitoring Subnet metrics or CloudWatchs Duration metrics to confirm invocations appear from each AZ. Include a canary test that fires if an AZs invocations drop to zero.

Spreading subnets across Availability Zones ensures the function continues to invoke even if one AZor its networking componentsbecomes unavailable.

References

  • AWS Lambda resilience guidance
  • Create more than one subnet across different AZ

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Lambda env vars and code artifacts with customer-managed KMS keys
countermeasure.desc:
Safeguard every sensitive value that AWS Lambda storesenvironment variables, .zip deployment packages, container images, and event-filter criteriaby encrypting them with an AWS KMS customer-managed key (CMK) instead of the default AWS-managed key. Using your own CMK lets you control key rotation, scope decrypt permissions tightly, and audit every use.

1 . Create or choose a CMK

aws kms create-key --description "Lambda data-at-rest CMK"
aws kms enable-key-rotation --key-id <key-id>

Limit the key policy to the Lambda service principal and the minimal set of roles that need kms:Decrypt / kms:GenerateDataKey.

2 . Encrypt environment variables

  • Console / IaC: set the KMS key ARN field (CloudFormation KmsKeyArn, Terraform kms_key_arn).
  • CLI:
    • aws lambda update-function-configuration \
          --function-name order-processor \
          --kms-key-arn arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd

Lambda now uses your CMK to encrypt Env Vars and event-filter JSON.

3 . Protect deployment artifacts

  • .zip packages in S3 store them in a bucket with SSE-KMS and the same CMK:
    • aws s3api put-bucket-encryption \
          --bucket lambda-artifacts-prod \
          --server-side-encryption-configuration \
          '{"Rules":[{"ApplyServerSideEncryptionByDefault":
             {"SSEAlgorithm":"aws:kms","KMSMasterKeyID":"alias/lambda-data"}}]}'
  • Container images in ECR ensure the ECR repository uses KMS encryption with your CMK.

4 . Grant least-privilege KMS access

Add this statement (scoped to the CMK ARN) to the functions execution role:

{
 "Effect": "Allow",
 "Action": [
   "kms:Decrypt",
   "kms:GenerateDataKey*"
 ],
 "Resource": "arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd"
}

5 . Continuous assurance

  • Enable AWS Config rule lambda-function-env-vars-encrypted (or a custom rule) to flag functions without a CMK.
  • Create CloudWatch alarms on KMS metric NumberOfFailedDecryptRequests.
  • Rotate the CMK annually; update KmsKeyArn in templates, then disable the old key after confirming no decrypt errors.

Encrypting Lambda data with your own KMS keys gives you full custody of cryptographic material, meets stringent compliance mandates, and lets you trace every decrypt back to an invoking principal.

References

  • Encrypting environment variables and artifacts with a customer-managed KMS key
  • Using AWS KMS keys with AWS Lambda

standard.ref: PM-17 Protecting Controlled Unclassified Information on External Systems

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Enforce bootstrap-aware CI/CD reviews and linting
countermeasure.desc:
To implement the security countermeasure that safeguards AWS Lambda custom runtimes by treating 'bootstrap' and Lambda runtime layers as sensitive code, follow the steps outlined below:

  1. Establish a Peer Review Process:
    • Define a policy that mandates peer reviews for any changes to files named 'bootstrap' or runtime layers containing 'bootstrap'.
    • Implement a system in your version control platform (e.g., GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket) that explicitly requires an "approval" label before merging code involving these sensitive components.
    • Ensure that reviewers are experienced in security practices and familiar with Lambda runtimes.
  2. Deploy Static Code Analysis Tools:
    • Integrate static analysis tools (e.g., Checkmarx, SonarQube) into the CI/CD pipeline.
    • Configure these tools to flag and fail builds when detected risky constructs such as:
      • curl, wget, or nc
      • Any usage of bash -c
      • Unchecked or blind network egress calls
    • Introduce an allowlist mechanism where risky constructs can only bypass checks if accompanied by a written, justified reason reviewed and approved by security teams.
  3. Restrict Bootstrap Role:
    • Verify that the 'bootstrap' file solely performs runtime initialization tasks and invokes the handler or Runtime Interface Client (RIC) as designed.
    • Apply rules to forbid any embedded persistence, telemetry beacons, or additional functionality within the 'bootstrap', unless explicitly approved through the peer-review process.
    • Audit the 'bootstrap' code periodically to ensure compliance with these restrictions.
  4. Enforce Pipeline-Only Deployment:
    • Block any direct uploads of Lambda runtime layers or the 'bootstrap' file via the AWS Management Console.
    • Configure permissions so that developers can only deploy changes through a CI/CD pipeline that enforces defined security checks.
    • Apply IAM policies to prevent unauthorized access to runtime layer modification workflows.

References

  • Unmasking Lambda's Hidden Threat - When Your Bootstrap Becomes a Backdoor
  • AWS Lambda Official Documentation
  • AWS CodePipeline Documentation
  • AWS Security Blog

countermeasure.name: Enforce code-signed Lambda deployments with AWS Signer
countermeasure.desc:
Guarantee that only vetted code reaches production by pairing AWS Signer with a Lambda Code Signing Configuration (CSC): every deployment package must be signed with your approved signing profile before Lambda accepts it.

  1. Create a signing profile
    1. aws signer put-signing-profile \
       --profile-name prod-lambda-code \
       --platform-id AWSLambda-SHA384-ECDSA
  2. Store the profile ARN in your CI/CD secrets.
  3. Integrate signing into the pipeline
    • Package the ZIP or container image, then call aws signer start-signing-job (ZIP) or ECR image signing (container).
    • Fail the build if the signing job status isnt Succeeded.
  4. Define a Code Signing Configuration
    1. aws lambda create-code-signing-config \
       --allowed-publishers SigningProfileVersionArns=arn:aws:signer::profile/prod-lambda-code/* \
       --code-signing-policies UntrustedArtifactOnDeployment=Enforce
  5. Enforce blocks any unsigned or differently-signed artifact.
  6. Attach the CSC to functions
    1. aws lambda update-function-code-signing-config \
       --function-name orders-handler \
       --code-signing-config-arn arn:aws:lambda::code-signing-config:csc-abc123
  7. Include this step in all CloudFormation/Terraform modules so drift is impossible.
  8. Guardrails & monitoring
    • Enable the AWS Config rule lambda-function-code-signing-config-enabled to detect functions without a CSC.
    • Use EventBridge to alert when a deployment fails due to CodeSigningError, signalling a bypass attempt or pipeline mis-sign.
  9. Key hygiene
    • Rotate the Signer KMS key annually; update the signing profile to the new key version.
    • Restrict signer:StartSigningJob permission to the build role; deny it in production accounts via SCPs.

By requiring AWS-signed packages and enforcing CSCs, you shut the door on tampered artifacts, typo-squatted libraries, and shadow deployments.

References

  • Code signing for AWS Lambda
  • AWS Signer Developer Guide

countermeasure.name: Enforce tagging standards on Lambda functions
countermeasure.desc:
Every Lambda function must carry a complete, standardized tag set for example Environment, Owner, CostCenter, and Compliance so that security, cost-allocation, and automation workflows can rely on consistent metadata.

How to implement

  1. Define the mandatory keys in a central document (e.g., tagging-standard.md) and publish it to your IaC repository.
  2. Validate in the pipeline
    • Add a build step (cfn-lint/Checkov/GitHub Action, etc.) that fails if the template or aws lambda create-function command omits any required tag.
  3. Enforce at runtime with AWS Config
    • Enable the managed rule required-tags or deploy a custom rule that checks the AWS::Lambda::Function resource type and your mandatory tag list.
    • Configure the rule for continuous evaluation and send non-compliant findings to Security Hub or an SNS topic that opens a ticket.
  4. Auto-remediate or quarantine
    • Attach an EventBridge rule to run an SSM Automation or Lambda fixer script that adds missing tagsor, in strict environments, disables the function until tags are corrected.
  5. Review quarterly
    • Spot-check tag accuracy (e.g., does the Owner tag still map to an active identity?) and update the standard when new reporting requirements appear.

Automated tagging enforcement guarantees that every Lambda function can be located, costed, and governed, while eliminating drift caused by manual provisioning.

References

  • Tagging Lambda functions
  • AWS Config rule required-tags

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with perfect-forward-secrecy for all Lambda traffic
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure every network path that carries AWS Lambda control-plane or data-plane trafficCLI / SDK calls to the Lambda API, Function URLs, ALB/API Gateway invokes, VPC egress, and third-party integrationsnegotiates TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3 using PFS cipher suites (ECDHE or DHE). Disable legacy SSL/TLS versions and static-key ciphers to eliminate downgrade and session-key compromise risks.

Implementation guidance

  1. Runtime & library hardening
    • Use current AWS SDKs, AWS CLI v2, and OS packages (OpenSSL 1.1.1, Java 8 u181, .NET 4.6) that default to TLS 1.2+.
    • In container images or AMIs set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 and remove *_RSA_* suites from the cipher list.
  2. Outbound Lambda networking
    • When the function runs in a VPC, allow only TCP 443 to interface endpoints (S3, STS, Secrets Manager, etc.). Block port 80 in security groups and route tables.
    • For external calls, pin the destination to https:// URIs and verify certificates (e.g., with Python requests.verify=True).
  3. Inbound invoke paths
    • Function URLs: set AuthType=AWS_IAM or another auth method; TLS is auto-enforced by AWS but add a WAF rule that blocks any request with the X-Forwarded-Proto != https.
    • API Gateway / ALB: enable TLS 1.2 minimum on the custom domain or listener policy; prefer ELBSecurityPolicy-TLS13-1-2-Res-2021-06.
    • For IoT or custom MQTT, use certificates that advertise only TLS 1.2/1.3 and EC cipher suites.
  4. Central guardrails
    • Attach an SCP that denies lambda:InvokeFunctionUrl or execute-api:Invoke when aws:SecureTransport is false.
    • Deploy AWS Config rules or cfn-nag checks that fail if an ALB listener policy includes TLS 1.0/1.1 or if a VPC security group permits port 80 egress.
  5. Continuous verification
    • Add a CI test that attempts openssl s_client -connect lambda.<region>.amazonaws.com:443 -tls1_1 and expect failure; succeed with -tls1_2.
    • Scan AMIs and containers monthly with Inspector or OpenSCAP for outdated OpenSSL/LibreSSL versions.
  6. Incident response & patching
    • Subscribe to AWS Security Bulletins; redeploy all Lambda runtime layers when critical TLS CVEs are announced.
    • Rotate any function URL or API Gateway custom certificates that use deprecated algorithms (RSA-1024, SHA-1).

Following this control guarantees strong, modern encryption end-to-end, satisfying compliance frameworks and protecting Lambda workloads against passive interception and forward-decryption attacks.

References

  • TLS 1.2 to become the minimum for all AWS service endpoints
  • Best practices for AWS Lambda security

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1021 - Restrict Web-Based Content

countermeasure.name: Grant least-privilege IAM permissions to Lambda execution roles
countermeasure.desc:
Create a dedicated IAM role for every Lambda function and attach only the permissions the code truly needsnothing more, nothing wildcard.

  1. Inventory required actions
    • List each AWS API the function calls (e.g., dynamodb:PutItem, s3:GetObject, secretsmanager:GetSecretValue).
    • Add logs:CreateLogGroup, logs:CreateLogStream, and logs:PutLogEvents for basic logging if they arent provided by a shared policy.
  2. Author a scoped policy
    • Restrict Resource to exact ARNs (specific table, bucket prefix, secret) instead of *.
    • Where possible, add condition keysfor example dynamodb:LeadingKeys, s3:prefix, aws:SourceVpc, or tagbased conditions.
  3. Attach the policy to a unique execution role
    • Console: Configuration Permissions choose or create role.
    • IaC example (CloudFormation):
      • LambdaRole:
         Type: AWS::IAM::Role
         Properties:
           AssumeRolePolicyDocument:
             Statement:
               - Effect: Allow
                 Principal: Service: lambda.amazonaws.com
                 Action: sts:AssumeRole
           Policies:
             - PolicyName: OrdersFunctionPolicy
               PolicyDocument: {...}   # actions/resources from step 2
  4. Remove default privileges
    • Delete unused AWS-managed policies like AWSLambdaFullAccess.
    • Never attach AdministratorAccess or * actionsfail the pipeline if these appear.
  5. Continuous validation
    • Enable IAM Access Analyzer unused permissions and prune actions that havent been called for 90 days.
    • Deploy AWS Config rule iam-managed-policy-check or a cfn-nag/Checkov rule in CI to block wildcard actions or resources.
  6. Review regularly
    • Re-run Access Analyzer after each feature release.
    • Rotate any secrets or keys the function accesses, updating the role policy as needed.

Applying strict, role-specific policies limits blast radius, supports the principle of least privilege, and satisfies compliance auditors looking for excessive permissions.

References

  • Security best practices for AWS Lambda
  • IAM Access Analyzer

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Isolate Lambda network traffic with locked-down VPC subnets and security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Run every Lambda function inside a dedicated set of private subnets and attach it to a least-privilege security group so the function can reach only the services it truly needsnothing else.

How to implement

  1. Create lambda-only private subnets
    • Place them in the application VPC but do not route them to an Internet Gateway.
    • If outbound internet access is required, send traffic through a shared NAT Gateway or a VPC endpoint (for S3, DynamoDB, etc.).
  2. Define a restrictive security group
    • Egress rules: allow only the ports and CIDRs (or other SGs) that correspond to your dependenciesfor example, TCP 5432 to an RDS SG, HTTPS (443) to a Secrets Manager VPC endpoint SG. Remove the default all traffic egress rule.
    • Ingress rules: normally none are required; Lambda creates connections out of the subnet. If the function must be called by an internal ALB, allow only that ALBs SG on the listener port.
  3. Attach the VPC config to the function
    1. aws lambda update-function-configuration \
       --function-name payment-handler \
       --vpc-config SubnetIds=subnet-0aa123,subnet-0bb456 \
                   SecurityGroupIds=sg-0lambda
  4. Guardrails and drift detection
    • Add an AWS Config rule (or cfn-nag/Checkov policy) that fails if a Lambda SG allows 0.0.0.0/0 or if the subnet route table points to an Internet Gateway.
    • Monitor VPC Flow Logs for unexpected destinations; tighten SG rules when new patterns appear.
  5. Document and review
    • Keep subnet IDs and SG IDs in your IaC modules so every environment uses the same isolation model.
    • Re-evaluate access rules quarterly or whenever the functions dependencies change.

Locking Lambda functions into isolated subnets and SGs minimizes lateral movement, reduces the attack surface, and satisfies segmentation requirements without sacrificing performance.

References

  • Configuring a Lambda function to access VPC resources
  • AWS Lambda security best practices network isolation

countermeasure.name: Keep Lambda functions on supported runtimes
countermeasure.desc:
AWS periodically deprecates Lambda runtimes (Node .js, Python, Java, .NET, Ruby, Go). A function that keeps running on an out-of-support runtime no longer receives security patches, and AWS may block deployments after the end-of-life date.

Implementation guidance

  1. Baseline now list every function and its runtime:
    1. aws lambda list-functions --query 'Functions[*].[FunctionName,Runtime]' --output table

Flag anything marked deprecated in the [runtime support policy].

  1. Automate continuous checks
    • Enable the managed AWS Config rule lambda-function-running-supported-runtime (or a custom rule) so any function on an outdated runtime is immediately marked NON_COMPLIANT.
    • Forward Config notifications to an SNS topic tied to your ticketing system or ChatOps channel.
  2. Update promptly
    • Track AWS deprecation announcements; add the EOL date to your backlog.
    • Use feature branches to bump the runtime version in your IaC (SAM/CloudFormation/Terraform) and CI pipeline, run tests, then deploy.
    • For container images, rebuild from an up-to-date base image and push a new tag.
  3. Prevent drift
    • Add a pipeline gate that rejects any create-function or update-function-configuration call if the --runtime flag is not in your approved list.
    • For containers, scan the image in CodeBuild/CodePipeline with AWS Inspector or Trivy before deployment.
  4. Review quarterly
    Re-run the baseline script or a Config compliance report; remove any temporary suppression and schedule upgrades for newly announced EOL runtimes.

Keeping all functions on supported runtimes guarantees ongoing security patches, performance optimisations, and access to the latest Lambda features.

References

  • AWS Lambda runtimes supported versions and deprecation policy
  • AWS Config rule lambda-function-running-supported-runtime
